INTRODUCTION.
line: INTRODUCTION.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Scepticism is as much the result of knowledge, as knowledge is of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: scepticism. To be content with what we at present know, is, for the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: most part, to shut our ears against conviction; since, from the very

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: gradual character of our education, we must continually forget, and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: emancipate ourselves from, knowledge previously acquired; we must set

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: aside old notions and embrace fresh ones; and, as we learn, we must be

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: daily unlearning something which it has cost us no small labour and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: anxiety to acquire.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: And this difficulty attaches itself more closely to an age in which

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: progress has gained a strong ascendency over prejudice, and in which

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: persons and things are, day by day, finding their real level, in lieu

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of their conventional value. The same principles which have swept away

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: traditional abuses, and which are making rapid havoc among the revenues

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of sinecurists, and stripping the thin, tawdry veil from attractive

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: superstitions, are working as actively in literature as in society. The

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: credulity of one writer, or the partiality of another, finds as

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: powerful a touchstone and as wholesome a chastisement in the healthy

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: scepticism of a temperate class of antagonists, as the dreams of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: conservatism, or the impostures of pluralist sinecures in the Church.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: History and tradition, whether of ancient or comparatively recent

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: times, are subjected to very different handling from that which the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: indulgence or credulity of former ages could allow. Mere statements are

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: jealously watched, and the motives of the writer form as important an

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: ingredient in the analysis of his history, as the facts he records.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Probability is a powerful and troublesome test; and it is by this

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: troublesome standard that a large portion of historical evidence is

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: sifted. Consistency is no less pertinacious and exacting in its

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: demands. In brief, to write a history, we must know more than mere

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: facts. Human nature, viewed under an induction of extended experience,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: is the best help to the criticism of human history. Historical

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: characters can only be estimated by the standard which human

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: experience, whether actual or traditionary, has furnished. To form

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: correct views of individuals we must regard them as forming parts of a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: great whole—we must measure them by their relation to the mass of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: beings by whom they are surrounded, and, in contemplating the incidents

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: in their lives or condition which tradition has handed down to us, we

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: must rather consider the general bearing of the whole narrative, than

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the respective probability of its details.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: It is unfortunate for us, that, of some of the greatest men, we know

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: least, and talk most. Homer, Socrates, and Shakespere[1] have, perhaps,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: contributed more to the intellectual enlightenment of mankind than any

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: other three writers who could be named, and yet the history of all

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: three has given rise to a boundless ocean of discussion, which has left

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: us little save the option of choosing which theory or theories we will

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: follow. The personality of Shakespere is, perhaps, the only thing in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: which critics will allow us to believe without controversy; but upon

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: everything else, even down to the authorship of plays, there is more or

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: less of doubt and uncertainty. Of Socrates we know as little as the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: contradictions of Plato and Xenophon will allow us to know. He was one

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of the _dramatis personæ_ in two dramas as unlike in principles as in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: style. He appears as the enunciator of opinions as different in their

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: tone as those of the writers who have handed them down. When we have

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: read Plato _or_ Xenophon, we think we know something of Socrates; when

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: we have fairly read and examined both, we feel convinced that we are

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: something worse than ignorant.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: It has been an easy, and a popular expedient, of late years, to deny

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the personal or real existence of men and things whose life and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: condition were too much for our belief. This system—which has often

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: comforted the religious sceptic, and substituted the consolations of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Strauss for those of the New Testament—has been of incalculable value

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: to the historical theorists of the last and present centuries. To

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: question the existence of Alexander the Great, would be a more

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: excusable act, than to believe in that of Romulus. To deny a fact

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: related in Herodotus, because it is inconsistent with a theory

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: developed from an Assyrian inscription which no two scholars read in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the same way, is more pardonable, than to believe in the good-natured

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: old king whom the elegant pen of Florian has idealized—_Numa

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Pompilius._

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Scepticism has attained its culminating point with respect to Homer,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and the state of our Homeric knowledge may be described as a free

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: permission to believe any theory, provided we throw overboard all

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: written tradition, concerning the author or authors of the Iliad and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Odyssey. What few authorities exist on the subject, are summarily

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: dismissed, although the arguments appear to run in a circle. “This

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: cannot be true, because it is not true; and, that is not true, because

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: it cannot be true.” Such seems to be the style, in which testimony upon

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: testimony, statement upon statement, is consigned to denial and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: oblivion.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: It is, however, unfortunate that the professed biographies of Homer are

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: partly forgeries, partly freaks of ingenuity and imagination, in which

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: truth is the requisite most wanting. Before taking a brief review of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the Homeric theory in its present conditions, some notice must be taken

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of the treatise on the Life of Homer which has been attributed to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Herodotus.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: According to this document, the city of Cumæ in Æolia, was, at an

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: early period, the seat of frequent immigrations from various parts of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Greece. Among the immigrants was Menapolus, the son of Ithagenes.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Although poor, he married, and the result of the union was a girl named

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Critheïs. The girl was left an orphan at an early age, under the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: guardianship of Cleanax, of Argos. It is to the indiscretion of this

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: maiden that we “are indebted for so much happiness.” Homer was the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: first fruit of her juvenile frailty, and received the name of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Melesigenes, from having been born near the river Meles, in Bœotia,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: whither Critheïs had been transported in order to save her reputation.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “At this time,” continues our narrative, “there lived at Smyrna a man

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: named Phemius, a teacher of literature and music, who, not being

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: married, engaged Critheïs to manage his household, and spin the flax he

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: received as the price of his scholastic labours. So satisfactory was

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: her performance of this task, and so modest her conduct, that he made

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: proposals of marriage, declaring himself, as a further inducement,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: willing to adopt her son, who, he asserted, would become a clever man,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: if he were carefully brought up.”

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: They were married; careful cultivation ripened the talents which nature

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: had bestowed, and Melesigenes soon surpassed his schoolfellows in every

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: attainment, and, when older, rivalled his preceptor in wisdom. Phemius

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: died, leaving him sole heir to his property, and his mother soon

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: followed. Melesigenes carried on his adopted father’s school with great

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: success, exciting the admiration not only of the inhabitants of Smyrna,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: but also of the strangers whom the trade carried on there, especially

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: in the exportation of corn, attracted to that city. Among these

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: visitors, one Mentes, from Leucadia, the modern Santa Maura, who

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: evinced a knowledge and intelligence rarely found in those times,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: persuaded Melesigenes to close his school, and accompany him on his

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: travels. He promised not only to pay his expenses, but to furnish him

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: with a further stipend, urging, that, “While he was yet young, it was

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: fitting that he should see with his own eyes the countries and cities

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: which might hereafter be the subjects of his discourses.” Melesigenes

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: consented, and set out with his patron, “examining all the curiosities

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of the countries they visited, and informing himself of everything by

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: interrogating those whom he met.” We may also suppose, that he wrote

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: memoirs of all that he deemed worthy of preservation.[2] Having set

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: sail from Tyrrhenia and Iberia, they reached Ithaca. Here Melesigenes,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: who had already suffered in his eyes, became much worse, and Mentes,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: who was about to leave for Leucadia, left him to the medical

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: superintendence of a friend of his, named Mentor, the son of Alcinor.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Under his hospitable and intelligent host, Melesigenes rapidly became

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: acquainted with the legends respecting Ulysses, which afterwards formed

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the subject of the Odyssey. The inhabitants of Ithaca assert, that it

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: was here that Melesigenes became blind, but the Colophomans make their

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: city the seat of that misfortune. He then returned to Smyrna, where he

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: applied himself to the study of poetry.[3]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: But poverty soon drove him to Cumæ. Having passed over the Hermæan

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: plain, he arrived at Neon Teichos, the New Wall, a colony of Cumæ.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Here his misfortunes and poetical talent gained him the friendship of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: one Tychias, an armourer. “And up to my time,” continued the author,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: “the inhabitants showed the place where he used to sit when giving a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: recitation of his verses, and they greatly honoured the spot. Here also

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: a poplar grew, which they said had sprung up ever since Melesigenes

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: arrived”.[4]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: But poverty still drove him on, and he went by way of Larissa, as being

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the most convenient road. Here, the Cumans say, he composed an epitaph

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: on Gordius, king of Phrygia, which has however, and with greater

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: probability, been attributed to Cleobulus of Lindus.[5]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Arrived at Cumæ, he frequented the _converzationes_[6] of the old men,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and delighted all by the charms of his poetry. Encouraged by this

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: favourable reception, he declared that, if they would allow him a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: public maintenance, he would render their city most gloriously

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: renowned. They avowed their willingness to support him in the measure

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: he proposed, and procured him an audience in the council. Having made

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the speech, with the purport of which our author has forgotten to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: acquaint us, he retired, and left them to debate respecting the answer

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: to be given to his proposal.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: The greater part of the assembly seemed favourable to the poet’s

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: demand, but one man observed that “if they were to feed _Homers_, they

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: would be encumbered with a multitude of useless people.” “From this

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: circumstance,” says the writer, “Melesigenes acquired the name of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homer, for the Cumans call blind men _Homers_.”[7] With a love of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: economy, which shows how similar the world has always been in its

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: treatment of literary men, the pension was denied, and the poet vented

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: his disappointment in a wish that Cumæa might never produce a poet

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: capable of giving it renown and glory.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: At Phocœa, Homer was destined to experience another literary distress.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: One Thestorides, who aimed at the reputation of poetical genius, kept

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homer in his own house, and allowed him a pittance, on condition of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: verses of the poet passing in his name. Having collected sufficient

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: poetry to be profitable, Thestorides, like some would-be-literary

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: publishers, neglected the man whose brains he had sucked, and left him.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: At his departure, Homer is said to have observed: “O Thestorides, of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the many things hidden from the knowledge of man, nothing is more

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: unintelligible than the human heart.”[8]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Homer continued his career of difficulty and distress, until some Chian

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: merchants, struck by the similarity of the verses they heard him

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: recite, acquainted him with the fact that Thestorides was pursuing a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: profitable livelihood by the recital of the very same poems. This at

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: once determined him to set out for Chios. No vessel happened then to be

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: setting sail thither, but he found one ready to start for Erythræ, a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: town of Ionia, which faces that island, and he prevailed upon the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: seamen to allow him to accompany them. Having embarked, he invoked a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: favourable wind, and prayed that he might be able to expose the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: imposture of Thestorides, who, by his breach of hospitality, had drawn

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: down the wrath of Jove the Hospitable.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: At Erythræ, Homer fortunately met with a person who had known him in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Phocœa, by whose assistance he at length, after some difficulty,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: reached the little hamlet of Pithys. Here he met with an adventure,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: which we will continue in the words of our author. “Having set out from

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Pithys, Homer went on, attracted by the cries of some goats that were

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: pasturing. The dogs barked on his approach, and he cried out. Glaucus

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: (for that was the name of the goat-herd) heard his voice, ran up

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: quickly, called off his dogs, and drove them away from Homer. For some

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: time he stood wondering how a blind man should have reached such a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: place alone, and what could be his design in coming. He then went up to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: him, and inquired who he was, and how he had come to desolate places

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and untrodden spots, and of what he stood in need. Homer, by recounting

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: to him the whole history of his misfortunes, moved him with compassion;

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and he took him, and led him to his cot, and having lit a fire, bade

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: him sup.[9]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “The dogs, instead of eating, kept barking at the stranger, according

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: to their usual habit. Whereupon Homer addressed Glaucus thus: O

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Glaucus, my friend, prythee attend to my behest. First give the dogs

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: their supper at the doors of the hut: for so it is better, since,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: whilst they watch, nor thief nor wild beast will approach the fold.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Glaucus was pleased with the advice, and marvelled at its author.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Having finished supper, they banqueted[10] afresh on conversation,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homer narrating his wanderings, and telling of the cities he had

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: visited.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: At length they retired to rest; but on the following morning, Glaucus

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: resolved to go to his master, and acquaint him with his meeting with

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homer. Having left the goats in charge of a fellow-servant, he left

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homer at home, promising to return quickly. Having arrived at Bolissus,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: a place near the farm, and finding his mate, he told him the whole

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: story respecting Homer and his journey. He paid little attention to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: what he said, and blamed Glaucus for his stupidity in taking in and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: feeding maimed and enfeebled persons. However, he bade him bring the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: stranger to him.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Glaucus told Homer what had taken place, and bade him follow him,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: assuring him that good fortune would be the result. Conversation soon

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: showed that the stranger was a man of much cleverness and general

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: knowledge, and the Chian persuaded him to remain, and to undertake the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: charge of his children.[11]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Besides the satisfaction of driving the impostor Thestorides from the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: island, Homer enjoyed considerable success as a teacher. In the town of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Chios he established a school where he taught the precepts of poetry.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: “To this day,” says Chandler,[12] “the most curious remaining is that

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: which has been named, without reason, the School of Homer. It is on the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: coast, at some distance from the city, northward, and appears to have

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: been an open temple of Cybele, formed on the top of a rock. The shape

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: is oval, and in the centre is the image of the goddess, the head and an

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: arm wanting. She is represented, as usual, sitting. The chair has a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: lion carved on each side, and on the back. The area is bounded by a low

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: rim, or seat, and about five yards over. The whole is hewn out of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: mountain, is rude, indistinct, and probably of the most remote

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: antiquity.”

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: So successful was this school, that Homer realised a considerable

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: fortune. He married, and had two daughters, one of whom died single,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the other married a Chian.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: The following passage betrays the same tendency to connect the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: personages of the poems with the history of the poet, which has already

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: been mentioned:—

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “In his poetical compositions Homer displays great gratitude towards

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Mentor of Ithaca, in the Odyssey, whose name he has inserted in his

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: poem as the companion of Ulysses,[13] in return for the care taken of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: him when afflicted with blindness. He also testifies his gratitude to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Phemius, who had given him both sustenance and instruction.”

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: His celebrity continued to increase, and many persons advised him to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: visit Greece, whither his reputation had now extended. Having, it is

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: said, made some additions to his poems calculated to please the vanity

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of the Athenians, of whose city he had hitherto made no mention,[14] he

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: sent out for Samos. Here being recognized by a Samian, who had met with

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: him in Chios, he was handsomely received, and invited to join in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: celebrating the Apaturian festival. He recited some verses, which gave

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: great satisfaction, and by singing the Eiresione at the New Moon

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: festivals, he earned a subsistence, visiting the houses of the rich,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: with whose children he was very popular.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: In the spring he sailed for Athens, and arrived at the island of Ios,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: now Ino, where he fell extremely ill, and died. It is said that his

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: death arose from vexation, at not having been able to unravel an enigma

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: proposed by some fishermen’s children.[15]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Such is, in brief, the substance of the earliest life of Homer we

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: possess, and so broad are the evidences of its historical

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: worthlessness, that it is scarcely necessary to point them out in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: detail. Let us now consider some of the opinions to which a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: persevering, patient, and learned—but by no means consistent—series of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: investigations has led. In doing so, I profess to bring forward

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: statements, not to vouch for their reasonableness or probability.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “Homer appeared. The history of this poet and his works is lost in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: doubtful obscurity, as is the history of many of the first minds who

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: have done honour to humanity, because they rose amidst darkness. The

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: majestic stream of his song, blessing and fertilizing, flows like the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Nile, through many lands and nations; and, like the sources of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Nile, its fountains will ever remain concealed.”

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Such are the words in which one of the most judicious German critics

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: has eloquently described the uncertainty in which the whole of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homeric question is involved. With no less truth and feeling he

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: proceeds:—

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “It seems here of chief importance to expect no more than the nature of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: things makes possible. If the period of tradition in history is the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: region of twilight, we should not expect in it perfect light. The

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: creations of genius always seem like miracles, because they are, for

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the most part, created far out of the reach of observation. If we were

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: in possession of all the historical testimonies, we never could wholly

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: explain the origin of the Iliad and the Odyssey; for their origin, in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: all essential points, must have remained the secret of the poet.”[16]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: From this criticism, which shows as much insight into the depths of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: human nature as into the minute wire-drawings of scholastic

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: investigation, let us pass on to the main question at issue. Was Homer

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: an individual?[17] or were the Iliad and Odyssey the result of an

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: ingenious arrangement of fragments by earlier poets?

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Well has Landor remarked: “Some tell us there were twenty Homers; some

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: deny that there was ever one. It were idle and foolish to shake the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: contents of a vase, in order to let them settle at last. We are

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: perpetually labouring to destroy our delights, our composure, our

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: devotion to superior power. Of all the animals on earth we least know

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: what is good for us. My opinion is, that what is best for us is our

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: admiration of good. No man living venerates Homer more than I do.”[18]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: But, greatly as we admire the generous enthusiasm which rests contented

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: with the poetry on which its best impulses had been nurtured and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: fostered, without seeking to destroy the vividness of first impressions

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: by minute analysis—our editorial office compels us to give some

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: attention to the doubts and difficulties with which the Homeric

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: question is beset, and to entreat our reader, for a brief period, to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: prefer his judgment to his imagination, and to condescend to dry

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: details.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Before, however, entering into particulars respecting the question of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: this unity of the Homeric poems, (at least of the Iliad,) I must

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: express my sympathy with the sentiments expressed in the following

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: remarks:—

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “We cannot but think the universal admiration of its unity by the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: better, the poetic age of Greece, almost conclusive testimony to its

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: original composition. It was not till the age of the grammarians that

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: its primitive integrity was called in question; nor is it injustice to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: assert, that the minute and analytical spirit of a grammarian is not

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the best qualification for the profound feeling, the comprehensive

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: conception of an harmonious whole. The most exquisite anatomist may be

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: no judge of the symmetry of the human frame: and we would take the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: opinion of Chantrey or Westmacott on the proportions and general beauty

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of a form, rather than that of Mr. Brodie or Sir Astley Cooper.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “There is some truth, though some malicious exaggeration, in the lines

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of Pope.—

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “‘The critic eye—that microscope of wit

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Sees hairs and pores, examines bit by bit,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: How parts relate to parts, or they to whole,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: The body’s harmony, the beaming soul,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Are things which Kuster, Burmann, Wasse, shall see,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: When man’s whole frame is obvious to a flea.’”[19]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Long was the time which elapsed before any one dreamt of questioning

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the unity of the authorship of the Homeric poems. The grave and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: cautious Thucydides quoted without hesitation the Hymn to Apollo,[20]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the authenticity of which has been already disclaimed by modern

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: critics. Longinus, in an oft quoted passage, merely expressed an

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: opinion touching the comparative inferiority of the Odyssey to the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Iliad,[21] and, among a mass of ancient authors, whose very names[22]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: it would be tedious to detail, no suspicion of the personal

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: non-existence of Homer ever arose. So far, the voice of antiquity seems

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: to be in favour of our early ideas on the subject; let us now see what

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: are the discoveries to which more modern investigations lay claim.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: At the end of the seventeenth century, doubts had begun to awaken on

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the subject, and we find Bentley remarking that “Homer wrote a sequel

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of songs and rhapsodies, to be sung by himself, for small comings and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: good cheer, at festivals and other days of merriment. These loose songs

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: were not collected together, in the form of an epic poem, till about

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Peisistratus’ time, about five hundred years after.”[23]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Two French writers—Hedelin and Perrault—avowed a similar scepticism on

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the subject; but it is in the “Scienza Nuova” of Battista Vico, that we

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: first meet with the germ of the theory, subsequently defended by Wolf

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: with so much learning and acuteness. Indeed, it is with the Wolfian

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: theory that we have chiefly to deal, and with the following bold

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: hypothesis, which we will detail in the words of Grote:—[24]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “Half a century ago, the acute and valuable Prolegomena of F. A. Wolf,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: turning to account the Venetian Scholia, which had then been recently

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: published, first opened philosophical discussion as to the history of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the Homeric text. A considerable part of that dissertation (though by

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: no means the whole) is employed in vindicating the position, previously

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: announced by Bentley, amongst others, that the separate constituent

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: portions of the Iliad and Odyssey had not been cemented together into

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: any compact body and unchangeable order, until the days of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Peisistratus, in the sixth century before Christ. As a step towards

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: that conclusion, Wolf maintained that no written copies of either poem

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: could be shown to have existed during the earlier times, to which their

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: composition is referred; and that without writing, neither the perfect

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: symmetry of so complicated a work could have been originally conceived

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: by any poet, nor, if realized by him, transmitted with assurance to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: posterity. The absence of easy and convenient writing, such as must be

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: indispensably supposed for long manuscripts, among the early Greeks,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: was thus one of the points in Wolf’s case against the primitive

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: integrity of the Iliad and Odyssey. By Nitzsch, and other leading

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: opponents of Wolf, the connection of the one with the other seems to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: have been accepted as he originally put it; and it has been considered

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: incumbent on those who defended the ancient aggregate character of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Iliad and Odyssey, to maintain that they were written poems from the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: beginning.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “To me it appears, that the architectonic functions ascribed by Wolf to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Peisistratus and his associates, in reference to the Homeric poems, are

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: nowise admissible. But much would undoubtedly be gained towards that

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: view of the question, if it could be shown, that, in order to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: controvert it, we were driven to the necessity of admitting long

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: written poems, in the ninth century before the Christian æra. Few

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: things, in my opinion, can be more improbable; and Mr. Payne Knight,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: opposed as he is to the Wolfian hypothesis, admits this no less than

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Wolf himself. The traces of writing in Greece, even in the seventh

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: century before the Christian æra, are exceedingly trifling. We have no

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: remaining inscription earlier than the fortieth Olympiad, and the early

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: inscriptions are rude and unskilfully executed; nor can we even assure

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: ourselves whether Archilochus, Simonidês of Amorgus, Kallinus,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Tyrtæus, Xanthus, and the other early elegiac and lyric poets,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: committed their compositions to writing, or at what time the practice

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of doing so became familiar. The first positive ground which authorizes

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: us to presume the existence of a manuscript of Homer, is in the famous

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: ordinance of Solôn, with regard to the rhapsodies at the Panathenæa:

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: but for what length of time previously manuscripts had existed, we are

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: unable to say.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “Those who maintain the Homeric poems to have been written from the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: beginning, rest their case, not upon positive proofs, nor yet upon the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: existing habits of society with regard to poetry—for they admit

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: generally that the Iliad and Odyssey were not read, but recited and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: heard,—but upon the supposed necessity that there must have been

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: manuscripts to ensure the preservation of the poems—the unassisted

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: memory of reciters being neither sufficient nor trustworthy. But here

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: we only escape a smaller difficulty by running into a greater; for the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: existence of trained bards, gifted with extraordinary memory,[25] is

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: far less astonishing than that of long manuscripts, in an age

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: essentially non-reading and non-writing, and when even suitable

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: instruments and materials for the process are not obvious. Moreover,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: there is a strong positive reason for believing that the bard was under

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: no necessity of refreshing his memory by consulting a manuscript; for

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: if such had been the fact, blindness would have been a disqualification

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: for the profession, which we know that it was not, as well from the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: example of Demodokus, in the Odyssey, as from that of the blind bard of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Chios, in the Hymn to the Delian Apollo, whom Thucydides, as well as

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the general tenor of Grecian legend, identifies with Homer himself. The

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: author of that hymn, be he who he may, could never have described a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: blind man as attaining the utmost perfection in his art, if he had been

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: conscious that the memory of the bard was only maintained by constant

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: reference to the manuscript in his chest.”

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: The loss of the digamma, that _crux_ of critics, that quicksand upon

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: which even the acumen of Bentley was shipwrecked, seems to prove beyond

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: a doubt, that the pronunciation of the Greek language had undergone a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: considerable change. Now it is certainly difficult to suppose that the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homeric poems could have suffered by this change, had written copies

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: been preserved. If Chaucer’s poetry, for instance, had not been

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: written, it could only have come down to us in a softened form, more

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: like the effeminate version of Dryden, than the rough, quaint, noble

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: original.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “At what period,” continues Grote, “these poems, or indeed any other

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Greek poems, first began to be written, must be matter of conjecture,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: though there is ground for assurance that it was before the time of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Solôn. If, in the absence of evidence, we may venture upon naming any

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: more determinate period, the question at once suggests itself, What

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: were the purposes which, in that state of society, a manuscript at its

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: first commencement must have been intended to answer? For whom was a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: written Iliad necessary? Not for the rhapsodes; for with them it was

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: not only planted in the memory, but also interwoven with the feelings,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and conceived in conjunction with all those flexions and intonations of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: voice, pauses, and other oral artifices which were required for

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: emphatic delivery, and which the naked manuscript could never

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: reproduce. Not for the general public—they were accustomed to receive

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: it with its rhapsodic delivery, and with its accompaniments of a solemn

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and crowded festival. The only persons for whom the written Iliad would

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: be suitable would be a select few; studious and curious men; a class of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: readers capable of analyzing the complicated emotions which they had

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: experienced as hearers in the crowd, and who would, on perusing the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: written words, realize in their imaginations a sensible portion of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: impression communicated by the reciter. Incredible as the statement may

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: seem in an age like the present, there is in all early societies, and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: there was in early Greece, a time when no such reading class existed.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: If we could discover at what time such a class first began to be

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: formed, we should be able to make a guess at the time when the old epic

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: poems were first committed to writing. Now the period which may with

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the greatest probability be fixed upon as having first witnessed the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: formation even of the narrowest reading class in Greece, is the middle

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of the seventh century before the Christian æra (B.C. 660 to B.C.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: 630), the age of Terpander, Kallinus, Archilochus, Simonidês of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Amorgus, &c. I ground this supposition on the change then operated in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the character and tendencies of Grecian poetry and music—the elegiac

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and the iambic measures having been introduced as rivals to the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: primitive hexameter, and poetical compositions having been transferred

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: from the epical past to the affairs of present and real life. Such a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: change was important at a time when poetry was the only known mode of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: publication (to use a modern phrase not altogether suitable, yet the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: nearest approaching to the sense). It argued a new way of looking at

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the old epical treasures of the people as well as a thirst for new

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: poetical effect; and the men who stood forward in it, may well be

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: considered as desirous to study, and competent to criticize, from their

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: own individual point of view, the written words of the Homeric

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: rhapsodies, just as we are told that Kallinus both noticed and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: eulogized the Thebaïs as the production of Homer. There seems,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: therefore, ground for conjecturing that (for the use of this

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: newly-formed and important, but very narrow class), manuscripts of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homeric poems and other old epics,—the Thebaïs and the Cypria, as well

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: as the Iliad and the Odyssey,—began to be compiled towards the middle

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of the seventh century (B.C. 1); and the opening of Egypt to Grecian

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: commerce, which took place about the same period, would furnish

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: increased facilities for obtaining the requisite papyrus to write upon.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: A reading class, when once formed, would doubtless slowly increase, and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the number of manuscripts along with it; so that before the time of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Solôn, fifty years afterwards, both readers and manuscripts, though

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: still comparatively few, might have attained a certain recognized

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: authority, and formed a tribunal of reference against the carelessness

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of individual rhapsodes.”[26]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: But even Peisistratus has not been suffered to remain in possession of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the credit, and we cannot help feeling the force of the following

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: observations—

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “There are several incidental circumstances which, in our opinion,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: throw some suspicion over the whole history of the Peisistratid

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: compilation, at least over the theory, that the Iliad was cast into its

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: present stately and harmonious form by the directions of the Athenian

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: ruler. If the great poets, who flourished at the bright period of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Grecian song, of which, alas! we have inherited little more than the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: fame, and the faint echo, if Stesichorus, Anacreon, and Simonidês were

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: employed in the noble task of compiling the Iliad and Odyssey, so much

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: must have been done to arrange, to connect, to harmonize, that it is

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: almost incredible, that stronger marks of Athenian manufacture should

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: not remain. Whatever occasional anomalies may be detected, anomalies

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: which no doubt arise out of our own ignorance of the language of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homeric age, however the irregular use of the digamma may have

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: perplexed our Bentleys, to whom the name of Helen is said to have

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: caused as much disquiet and distress as the fair one herself among the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: heroes of her age, however Mr. Knight may have failed in reducing the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homeric language to its primitive form; however, finally, the Attic

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: dialect may not have assumed all its more marked and distinguishing

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: characteristics—still it is difficult to suppose that the language,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: particularly in the joinings and transitions, and connecting parts,

line: transform ourselves into heroes of the time being, we in imagination

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: must fight over the same battles, woo the same loves, burn with the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: same sense of injury, as an Achilles or a Hector. And if we can but

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: attain this degree of enthusiasm (and less enthusiasm will scarcely

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: suffice for the reading of Homer), we shall feel that the poems of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homer are not only the work of one writer, but of the greatest writer

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: that ever touched the hearts of men by the power of song.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: And it was this supposed unity of authorship which gave these poems

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: their powerful influence over the minds of the men of old. Heeren, who

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: is evidently little disposed in favour of modern theories, finely

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: observes:—

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “It was Homer who formed the character of the Greek nation. No poet has

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: ever, as a poet, exercised a similar influence over his countrymen.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Prophets, lawgivers, and sages have formed the character of other

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: nations; it was reserved to a poet to form that of the Greeks. This is

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: a feature in their character which was not wholly erased even in the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: period of their degeneracy. When lawgivers and sages appeared in

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Greece, the work of the poet had already been accomplished; and they

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: paid homage to his superior genius. He held up before his nation the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: mirror, in which they were to behold the world of gods and heroes no

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: less than of feeble mortals, and to behold them reflected with purity

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and truth. His poems are founded on the first feeling of human nature;

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: on the love of children, wife, and country; on that passion which

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: outweighs all others, the love of glory. His songs were poured forth

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: from a breast which sympathized with all the feelings of man; and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: therefore they enter, and will continue to enter, every breast which

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: cherishes the same sympathies. If it is granted to his immortal spirit,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: from another heaven than any of which he dreamed on earth, to look down

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: on his race, to see the nations from the fields of Asia to the forests

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of Hercynia, performing pilgrimages to the fountain which his magic

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: wand caused to flow; if it is permitted to him to view the vast

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: assemblage of grand, of elevated, of glorious productions, which had

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: been called into being by means of his songs; wherever his immortal

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: spirit may reside, this alone would suffice to complete his

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: happiness.”[35]

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Can we contemplate that ancient monument, on which the “Apotheosis of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Homer”[36] is depictured, and not feel how much of pleasing

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: association, how much that appeals most forcibly and most distinctly to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: our minds, is lost by the admittance of any theory but our old

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: tradition? The more we read, and the more we think—think as becomes the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: readers of Homer,—the more rooted becomes the conviction that the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Father of Poetry gave us this rich inheritance, whole and entire.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Whatever were the means of its preservation, let us rather be thankful

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: for the treasury of taste and eloquence thus laid open to our use, than

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: seek to make it a mere centre around which to drive a series of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: theories, whose wildness is only equalled by their inconsistency with

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: each other.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: As the hymns, and some other poems usually ascribed to Homer, are not

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: included in Pope’s translation, I will content myself with a brief

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: account of the Battle of the Frogs and Mice, from the pen of a writer

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: who has done it full justice[37]:—

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: “This poem,” says Coleridge, “is a short mock-heroic of ancient date.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: The text varies in different editions, and is obviously disturbed and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: corrupt to a great degree; it is commonly said to have been a juvenile

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: essay of Homer’s genius; others have attributed it to the same Pigrees,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: mentioned above, and whose reputation for humour seems to have invited

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the appropriation of any piece of ancient wit, the author of which was

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: uncertain; so little did the Greeks, before the age of the Ptolemies,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: know or care about that department of criticism employed in determining

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: the genuineness of ancient writings. As to this little poem being a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: youthful profusion of Homer, it seems sufficient to say that from the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: beginning to the end it is a plain and palpable parody, not only of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: general spirit, but of the numerous passages of the Iliad itself; and

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: even, if no such intention to parody were discernible in it, the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: objection would still remain, that to suppose a work of mere burlesque

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: to be the primary effort of poetry in a simple age, seems to reverse

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: that order in the development of national taste, which the history of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: every other people in Europe, and of many in Asia, has almost

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: ascertained to be a law of the human mind; it is in a state of society

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: much more refined and permanent than that described in the Iliad, that

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: any popularity would attend such a ridicule of war and the gods as is

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: contained in this poem; and the fact of there having existed three

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: other poems of the same kind attributed, for aught we can see, with as

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: much reason to Homer, is a strong inducement to believe that none of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: them were of the Homeric age. Knight infers from the usage of the word

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: deltos, “writing tablet,” instead of διφθέρα, “skin,” which, according

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: to Herod. 5, 58, was the material employed by the Asiatic Greeks for

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: that purpose, that this poem was another offspring of Attic ingenuity;

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and generally that the familiar mention of the cock (v. 191) is a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: strong argument against so ancient a date for its composition.”

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Having thus given a brief account of the poems comprised in Pope’s

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: design, I will now proceed to make a few remarks on his translation,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: and on my own purpose in the present edition.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: Pope was not a Grecian. His whole education had been irregular, and his

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: earliest acquaintance with the poet was through the version of Ogilby.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: It is not too much to say that his whole work bears the impress of a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: disposition to be satisfied with the general sense, rather than to dive

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: deeply into the minute and delicate features of language. Hence his

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: whole work is to be looked upon rather as an elegant paraphrase than a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: translation. There are, to be sure, certain conventional anecdotes,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: which prove that Pope consulted various friends, whose classical

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: attainments were sounder than his own, during the undertaking; but it

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: is probable that these examinations were the result rather of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: contradictory versions already existing, than of a desire to make a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: perfect transcript of the original. And in those days, what is called

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: literal translation was less cultivated than at present. If something

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: like the general sense could be decorated with the easy gracefulness of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: a practised poet; if the charms of metrical cadence and a pleasing

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: fluency could be made consistent with a fair interpretation of the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: poet’s meaning, his _words_ were less jealously sought for, and those

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: who could read so good a poem as Pope’s Iliad had fair reason to be

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: satisfied.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: It would be absurd, therefore, to test Pope’s translation by our own

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: advancing knowledge of the original text. We must be content to look at

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: it as a most delightful work in itself,—a work which is as much a part

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: of English literature as Homer himself is of Greek. We must not be torn

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: from our kindly associations with the old Iliad, that once was our most

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: cherished companion, or our most looked-for prize, merely because

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: Buttmann, Loewe, and Liddell have made us so much more accurate as to

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: ἀμφικύπελλον being an adjective, and not a substantive. Far be it from

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: us to defend the faults of Pope, especially when we think of Chapman’s

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: fine, bold, rough old English;—far be it from us to hold up his

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: translation as what a translation of Homer _might_ be. But we can still

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: dismiss Pope’s Iliad to the hands of our readers, with the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: consciousness that they must have read a very great number of books

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: before they have read its fellow.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
INTRODUCTION.
line: As to the Notes accompanying the present volume, they are drawn up

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: without pretension, and mainly with the view of helping the general

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: reader. Having some little time since translated all the works of Homer

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: for another publisher, I might have brought a large amount of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: accumulated matter, sometimes of a critical character, to bear upon the

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: text. But Pope’s version was no field for such a display; and my

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: purpose was to touch briefly on antiquarian or mythological allusions,

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: to notice occasionally _some_ departures from the original, and to give

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: a few parallel passages from our English Homer, Milton. In the latter

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: task I cannot pretend to novelty, but I trust that my other

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: annotations, while utterly disclaiming high scholastic views, will be

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: found to convey as much as is wanted; at least, as far as the necessary

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: limits of these volumes could be expected to admit. To write a

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: commentary on Homer is not my present aim; but if I have made Pope’s

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: translation a little more entertaining and instructive to a mass of

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: miscellaneous readers, I shall consider my wishes satisfactorily

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
line: accomplished.

Poem Title: INTRODUCTION.
THEODORE ALOIS BUCKLEY.

POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Homer is universally allowed to have had the greatest invention of any

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: writer whatever. The praise of judgment Virgil has justly contested

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: with him, and others may have their pretensions as to particular

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: excellences; but his invention remains yet unrivalled. Nor is it a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: wonder if he has ever been acknowledged the greatest of poets, who most

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: excelled in that which is the very foundation of poetry. It is the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: invention that, in different degrees, distinguishes all great geniuses:

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the utmost stretch of human study, learning, and industry, which

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: masters everything besides, can never attain to this. It furnishes art

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: with all her materials, and without it judgment itself can at best but

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: “steal wisely:” for art is only like a prudent steward that lives on

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: managing the riches of nature. Whatever praises may be given to works

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of judgment, there is not even a single beauty in them to which the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: invention must not contribute: as in the most regular gardens, art can

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: only reduce beauties of nature to more regularity, and such a figure,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: which the common eye may better take in, and is, therefore, more

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: entertained with. And, perhaps, the reason why common critics are

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: inclined to prefer a judicious and methodical genius to a great and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: fruitful one, is, because they find it easier for themselves to pursue

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: their observations through a uniform and bounded walk of art, than to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: comprehend the vast and various extent of nature.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Our author’s work is a wild paradise, where, if we cannot see all the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: beauties so distinctly as in an ordered garden, it is only because the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: number of them is infinitely greater. It is like a copious nursery,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: which contains the seeds and first productions of every kind, out of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: which those who followed him have but selected some particular plants,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: each according to his fancy, to cultivate and beautify. If some things

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: are too luxuriant it is owing to the richness of the soil; and if

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: others are not arrived to perfection or maturity, it is only because

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: they are overrun and oppressed by those of a stronger nature.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: It is to the strength of this amazing invention we are to attribute

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: that unequalled fire and rapture which is so forcible in Homer, that no

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: man of a true poetical spirit is master of himself while he reads him.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: What he writes is of the most animated nature imaginable; every thing

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: moves, every thing lives, and is put in action. If a council be called,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: or a battle fought, you are not coldly informed of what was said or

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: done as from a third person; the reader is hurried out of himself by

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the force of the poet’s imagination, and turns in one place to a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: hearer, in another to a spectator. The course of his verses resembles

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: that of the army he describes,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Οἵδ’ ἄῤ ἴσαν, ὡσεί τε πυρὶ χθὼν πἆσα νέμοιτο.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: “They pour along like a fire that sweeps the whole earth before it.” It

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: is, however, remarkable, that his fancy, which is everywhere vigorous,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: is not discovered immediately at the beginning of his poem in its

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: fullest splendour: it grows in the progress both upon himself and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: others, and becomes on fire, like a chariot-wheel, by its own rapidity.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Exact disposition, just thought, correct elocution, polished numbers,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: may have been found in a thousand; but this poetic fire, this “vivida

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: vis animi,” in a very few. Even in works where all those are imperfect

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: or neglected, this can overpower criticism, and make us admire even

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: while we disapprove. Nay, where this appears, though attended with

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: absurdities, it brightens all the rubbish about it, till we see nothing

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: but its own splendour. This fire is discerned in Virgil, but discerned

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: as through a glass, reflected from Homer, more shining than fierce, but

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: everywhere equal and constant: in Lucan and Statius it bursts out in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: sudden, short, and interrupted flashes: In Milton it glows like a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: furnace kept up to an uncommon ardour by the force of art: in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Shakspeare it strikes before we are aware, like an accidental fire from

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: heaven: but in Homer, and in him only, it burns everywhere clearly and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: everywhere irresistibly.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: I shall here endeavour to show how this vast invention exerts itself in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: a manner superior to that of any poet through all the main constituent

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: parts of his work: as it is the great and peculiar characteristic which

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: distinguishes him from all other authors.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: This strong and ruling faculty was like a powerful star, which, in the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: violence of its course, drew all things within its vortex. It seemed

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: not enough to have taken in the whole circle of arts, and the whole

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: compass of nature, to supply his maxims and reflections; all the inward

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: passions and affections of mankind, to furnish his characters: and all

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the outward forms and images of things for his descriptions: but

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: wanting yet an ampler sphere to expatiate in, he opened a new and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: boundless walk for his imagination, and created a world for himself in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the invention of fable. That which Aristotle calls “the soul of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: poetry,” was first breathed into it by Homer. I shall begin with

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: considering him in his part, as it is naturally the first; and I speak

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of it both as it means the design of a poem, and as it is taken for

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: fiction.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Fable may be divided into the probable, the allegorical, and the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: marvellous. The probable fable is the recital of such actions as,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: though they did not happen, yet might, in the common course of nature;

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: or of such as, though they did, became fables by the additional

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: episodes and manner of telling them. Of this sort is the main story of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: an epic poem, “The return of Ulysses, the settlement of the Trojans in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Italy,” or the like. That of the Iliad is the “anger of Achilles,” the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: most short and single subject that ever was chosen by any poet. Yet

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: this he has supplied with a vaster variety of incidents and events, and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: crowded with a greater number of councils, speeches, battles, and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: episodes of all kinds, than are to be found even in those poems whose

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: schemes are of the utmost latitude and irregularity. The action is

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: hurried on with the most vehement spirit, and its whole duration

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: employs not so much as fifty days. Virgil, for want of so warm a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: genius, aided himself by taking in a more extensive subject, as well as

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: a greater length of time, and contracting the design of both Homer’s

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: poems into one, which is yet but a fourth part as large as his. The

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: other epic poets have used the same practice, but generally carried it

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: so far as to superinduce a multiplicity of fables, destroy the unity of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: action, and lose their readers in an unreasonable length of time. Nor

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: is it only in the main design that they have been unable to add to his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: invention, but they have followed him in every episode and part of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: story. If he has given a regular catalogue of an army, they all draw up

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: their forces in the same order. If he has funeral games for Patroclus,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Virgil has the same for Anchises, and Statius (rather than omit them)

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: destroys the unity of his actions for those of Archemorus. If Ulysses

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: visit the shades, the Æneas of Virgil and Scipio of Silius are sent

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: after him. If he be detained from his return by the allurements of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: line to a beautiful agreement with its sense. If the Grecian poet has

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: not been so frequently celebrated on this account as the Roman, the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: only reason is, that fewer critics have understood one language than

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the other. Dionysius of Halicarnassus has pointed out many of our

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: author’s beauties in this kind, in his treatise of the Composition of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Words. It suffices at present to observe of his numbers, that they flow

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: with so much ease, as to make one imagine Homer had no other care than

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: to transcribe as fast as the Muses dictated, and, at the same time,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: with so much force and inspiriting vigour, that they awaken and raise

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: us like the sound of a trumpet. They roll along as a plentiful river,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: always in motion, and always full; while we are borne away by a tide of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: verse, the most rapid, and yet the most smooth imaginable.
