POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Thus on whatever side we contemplate Homer, what principally strikes us

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: is his invention. It is that which forms the character of each part of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: his work; and accordingly we find it to have made his fable more

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: extensive and copious than any other, his manners more lively and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: strongly marked, his speeches more affecting and transported, his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: sentiments more warm and sublime, his images and descriptions more full

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: and animated, his expression more raised and daring, and his numbers

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: more rapid and various. I hope, in what has been said of Virgil, with

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: regard to any of these heads, I have no way derogated from his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: character. Nothing is more absurd or endless, than the common method of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: comparing eminent writers by an opposition of particular passages in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: them, and forming a judgment from thence of their merit upon the whole.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: We ought to have a certain knowledge of the principal character and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: distinguishing excellence of each: it is in that we are to consider

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: him, and in proportion to his degree in that we are to admire him. No

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: author or man ever excelled all the world in more than one faculty; and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: as Homer has done this in invention, Virgil has in judgment. Not that

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: we are to think that Homer wanted judgment, because Virgil had it in a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: more eminent degree; or that Virgil wanted invention, because Homer

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: possessed a larger share of it; each of these great authors had more of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: both than perhaps any man besides, and are only said to have less in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: comparison with one another. Homer was the greater genius, Virgil the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: better artist. In one we most admire the man, in the other the work.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Homer hurries and transports us with a commanding impetuosity; Virgil

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: leads us with an attractive majesty; Homer scatters with a generous

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: profusion; Virgil bestows with a careful magnificence; Homer, like the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Nile, pours out his riches with a boundless overflow; Virgil, like a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: river in its banks, with a gentle and constant stream. When we behold

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: their battles, methinks the two poets resemble the heroes they

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: celebrate. Homer, boundless and resistless as Achilles, bears all

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: before him, and shines more and more as the tumult increases; Virgil,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: calmly daring, like Æneas, appears undisturbed in the midst of the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: action; disposes all about him, and conquers with tranquillity. And

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: when we look upon their machines, Homer seems like his own Jupiter in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: his terrors, shaking Olympus, scattering the lightnings, and firing the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: heavens: Virgil, like the same power in his benevolence, counselling

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: with the gods, laying plans for empires, and regularly ordering his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: whole creation.

POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: But after all, it is with great parts, as with great virtues, they

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: naturally border on some imperfection; and it is often hard to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: distinguish exactly where the virtue ends, or the fault begins. As

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: prudence may sometimes sink to suspicion, so may a great judgment

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: decline to coldness; and as magnanimity may run up to profusion or

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: extravagance, so may a great invention to redundancy or wildness. If we

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: look upon Homer in this view, we shall perceive the chief objections

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: against him to proceed from so noble a cause as the excess of this

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: faculty.

line: Among these we may reckon some of his marvellous fictions, upon which

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: so much criticism has been spent, as surpassing all the bounds of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: probability. Perhaps it may be with great and superior souls, as with

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: gigantic bodies, which, exerting themselves with unusual strength,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: exceed what is commonly thought the due proportion of parts, to become

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: miracles in the whole; and, like the old heroes of that make, commit

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: something near extravagance, amidst a series of glorious and inimitable

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: performances. Thus Homer has his “speaking horses;” and Virgil his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: “myrtles distilling blood;” where the latter has not so much as

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: contrived the easy intervention of a deity to save the probability.

POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: It is owing to the same vast invention, that his similes have been

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: thought too exuberant and full of circumstances. The force of this

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: faculty is seen in nothing more, than in its inability to confine

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: itself to that single circumstance upon which the comparison is

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: grounded: it runs out into embellishments of additional images, which,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: however, are so managed as not to overpower the main one. His similes

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: are like pictures, where the principal figure has not only its

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: proportion given agreeable to the original, but is also set off with

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: occasional ornaments and prospects. The same will account for his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: manner of heaping a number of comparisons together in one breath, when

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: his fancy suggested to him at once so many various and correspondent

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: images. The reader will easily extend this observation to more

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: objections of the same kind.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: If there are others which seem rather to charge him with a defect or

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: narrowness of genius, than an excess of it, those seeming defects will

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: be found upon examination to proceed wholly from the nature of the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: times he lived in. Such are his grosser representations of the gods;

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: and the vicious and imperfect manners of his heroes; but I must here

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: speak a word of the latter, as it is a point generally carried into

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: extremes, both by the censurers and defenders of Homer. It must be a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: strange partiality to antiquity, to think with Madame Dacier,[38] “that

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: those times and manners are so much the more excellent, as they are

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: more contrary to ours.” Who can be so prejudiced in their favour as to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: magnify the felicity of those ages, when a spirit of revenge and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: cruelty, joined with the practice of rapine and robbery, reigned

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: through the world: when no mercy was shown but for the sake of lucre;

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: when the greatest princes were put to the sword, and their wives and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: daughters made slaves and concubines? On the other side, I would not be

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: so delicate as those modern critics, who are shocked at the servile

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: offices and mean employments in which we sometimes see the heroes of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Homer engaged. There is a pleasure in taking a view of that simplicity,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: in opposition to the luxury of succeeding ages: in beholding monarchs

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: without their guards; princes tending their flocks, and princesses

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: drawing water from the springs. When we read Homer, we ought to reflect

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: that we are reading the most ancient author in the heathen world; and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: those who consider him in this light, will double their pleasure in the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: perusal of him. Let them think they are growing acquainted with nations

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: and people that are now no more; that they are stepping almost three

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: thousand years back into the remotest antiquity, and entertaining

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: themselves with a clear and surprising vision of things nowhere else to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: be found, the only true mirror of that ancient world. By this means

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: alone their greatest obstacles will vanish; and what usually creates

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: their dislike, will become a satisfaction.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: This consideration may further serve to answer for the constant use of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the same epithets to his gods and heroes; such as the “far-darting

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Phœbus,” the “blue-eyed Pallas,” the “swift-footed Achilles,” &c.,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: which some have censured as impertinent, and tediously repeated. Those

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of the gods depended upon the powers and offices then believed to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: belong to them; and had contracted a weight and veneration from the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: rites and solemn devotions in which they were used: they were a sort of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: attributes with which it was a matter of religion to salute them on all

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: occasions, and which it was an irreverence to omit. As for the epithets

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of great men, Mons. Boileau is of opinion, that they were in the nature

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of surnames, and repeated as such; for the Greeks having no names

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: derived from their fathers, were obliged to add some other distinction

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of each person; either naming his parents expressly, or his place of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: birth, profession, or the like: as Alexander the son of Philip,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Herodotus of Halicarnassus, Diogenes the Cynic, &c. Homer, therefore,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: complying with the custom of his country, used such distinctive

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: additions as better agreed with poetry. And, indeed, we have something

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: parallel to these in modern times, such as the names of Harold

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Harefoot, Edmund Ironside, Edward Longshanks, Edward the Black Prince,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: &c. If yet this be thought to account better for the propriety than for

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the repetition, I shall add a further conjecture. Hesiod, dividing the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: world into its different ages, has placed a fourth age, between the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: brazen and the iron one, of “heroes distinct from other men; a divine

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: race who fought at Thebes and Troy, are called demi-gods, and live by

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the care of Jupiter in the islands of the blessed.”[39] Now among the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: divine honours which were paid them, they might have this also in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: common with the gods, not to be mentioned without the solemnity of an

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: epithet, and such as might be acceptable to them by celebrating their

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: families, actions or qualities.

POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: What other cavils have been raised against Homer, are such as hardly

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: deserve a reply, but will yet be taken notice of as they occur in the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: course of the work. Many have been occasioned by an injudicious

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: endeavour to exalt Virgil; which is much the same, as if one should

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: think to raise the superstructure by undermining the foundation: one

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: would imagine, by the whole course of their parallels, that these

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: critics never so much as heard of Homer’s having written first; a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: consideration which whoever compares these two poets ought to have

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: always in his eye. Some accuse him for the same things which they

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: overlook or praise in the other; as when they prefer the fable and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: moral of the Æneis to those of the Iliad, for the same reasons which

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: might set the Odyssey above the Æneis; as that the hero is a wiser man,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: and the action of the one more beneficial to his country than that of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the other; or else they blame him for not doing what he never designed;

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: as because Achilles is not as good and perfect a prince as Æneas, when

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the very moral of his poem required a contrary character: it is thus

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: that Rapin judges in his comparison of Homer and Virgil. Others select

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: those particular passages of Homer which are not so laboured as some

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: that Virgil drew out of them: this is the whole management of Scaliger

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: in his Poetics. Others quarrel with what they take for low and mean

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: expressions, sometimes through a false delicacy and refinement, oftener

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: from an ignorance of the graces of the original, and then triumph in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the awkwardness of their own translations: this is the conduct of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Perrault in his Parallels. Lastly, there are others, who, pretending to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: a fairer proceeding, distinguish between the personal merit of Homer,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: and that of his work; but when they come to assign the causes of the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: great reputation of the Iliad, they found it upon the ignorance of his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: times, and the prejudice of those that followed; and in pursuance of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: this principle, they make those accidents (such as the contention of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the cities, &c.) to be the causes of his fame, which were in reality

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the consequences of his merit. The same might as well be said of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Virgil, or any great author whose general character will infallibly

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: raise many casual additions to their reputation. This is the method of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Mons. de la Mott; who yet confesses upon the whole that in whatever age

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Homer had lived, he must have been the greatest poet of his nation, and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: that he may be said in his sense to be the master even of those who

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: surpassed him.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: In all these objections we see nothing that contradicts his title to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the honour of the chief invention: and as long as this (which is indeed

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the characteristic of poetry itself) remains unequalled by his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: followers, he still continues superior to them. A cooler judgment may

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: commit fewer faults, and be more approved in the eyes of one sort of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: critics: but that warmth of fancy will carry the loudest and most

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: universal applauses which holds the heart of a reader under the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: strongest enchantment. Homer not only appears the inventor of poetry,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: but excels all the inventors of other arts, in this, that he has

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: swallowed up the honour of those who succeeded him. What he has done

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: admitted no increase, it only left room for contraction or regulation.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: He showed all the stretch of fancy at once; and if he has failed in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: some of his flights, it was but because he attempted everything. A work

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of this kind seems like a mighty tree, which rises from the most

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: vigorous seed, is improved with industry, flourishes, and produces the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: finest fruit: nature and art conspire to raise it; pleasure and profit

line: language: but it is a great mistake to imagine (as many have done) that

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: It is not to be doubted, that the fire of the poem is what a translator

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: managing: however, it is his safest way to be content with preserving

line: this to his utmost in the whole, without endeavouring to be more than

line: he finds his author is, in any particular place. It is a great secret

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: in writing, to know when to be plain, and when poetical and figurative;

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: and it is what Homer will teach us, if we will but follow modestly in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: his footsteps. Where his diction is bold and lofty, let us raise ours

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: as high as we can; but where his is plain and humble, we ought not to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: be deterred from imitating him by the fear of incurring the censure of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: a mere English critic. Nothing that belongs to Homer seems to have been

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: more commonly mistaken than the just pitch of his style: some of his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: translators having swelled into fustian in a proud confidence of the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: sublime; others sunk into flatness, in a cold and timorous notion of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: simplicity. Methinks I see these different followers of Homer, some

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: sweating and straining after him by violent leaps and bounds (the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: certain signs of false mettle), others slowly and servilely creeping in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: his train, while the poet himself is all the time proceeding with an

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: unaffected and equal majesty before them. However, of the two extremes

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: one could sooner pardon frenzy than frigidity; no author is to be

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: envied for such commendations, as he may gain by that character of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: style, which his friends must agree together to call simplicity, and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the rest of the world will call dulness. There is a graceful and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: much from each other as the air of a plain man from that of a sloven:

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: it is one thing to be tricked up, and another not to be dressed at all.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Simplicity is the mean between ostentation and rusticity.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: This pure and noble simplicity is nowhere in such perfection as in the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Scripture and our author. One may affirm, with all respect to the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: inspired writings, that the Divine Spirit made use of no other words

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: but what were intelligible and common to men at that time, and in that

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: part of the world; and, as Homer is the author nearest to those, his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: style must of course bear a greater resemblance to the sacred books

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: than that of any other writer. This consideration (together with what

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: has been observed of the parity of some of his thoughts) may, methinks,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: induce a translator, on the one hand, to give in to several of those

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: as, on the other, to avoid those which have been appropriated to the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Divinity, and in a manner consigned to mystery and religion.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: For a further preservation of this air of simplicity, a particular care

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: proverbial speeches which are so numerous in this poet. They have

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: gravity and shortness with which they are delivered: a grace which

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: would be utterly lost by endeavouring to give them what we call a more

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: ingenious (that is, a more modern) turn in the paraphrase.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

line: Perhaps the mixture of some Græcisms and old words after the manner of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Milton, if done without too much affectation, might not have an ill

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: effect in a version of this particular work, which most of any other

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: seems to require a venerable, antique cast. But certainly the use of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: or the like, (into which some of his translators have fallen) cannot be

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: allowable; those only excepted without which it is impossible to treat

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the subjects in any living language.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: There are two peculiarities in Homer’s diction, which are a sort of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: marks or moles by which every common eye distinguishes him at first

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: sight; those who are not his greatest admirers look upon them as

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: defects, and those who are, seemed pleased with them as beauties. I

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: speak of his compound epithets, and of his repetitions. Many of the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: former cannot be done literally into English without destroying the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: purity of our language. I believe such should be retained as slide

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: easily of themselves into an English compound, without violence to the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: ear or to the received rules of composition, as well as those which

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: have received a sanction from the authority of our best poets, and are

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: become familiar through their use of them; such as “the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: cloud-compelling Jove,” &c. As for the rest, whenever any can be as

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: fully and significantly expressed in a single word as in a compounded

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: one, the course to be taken is obvious.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Some that cannot be so turned, as to preserve their full image by one

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: or two words, may have justice done them by circumlocution; as the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: epithet einosiphyllos to a mountain, would appear little or ridiculous

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: translated literally “leaf-shaking,” but affords a majestic idea in the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: periphrasis: “the lofty mountain shakes his waving woods.” Others that

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: admit of different significations, may receive an advantage from a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: judicious variation, according to the occasions on which they are

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: introduced. For example, the epithet of Apollo, ἑκηβόλος or

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: “far-shooting,” is capable of two explications; one literal, in respect

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of the darts and bow, the ensigns of that god; the other allegorical,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: with regard to the rays of the sun; therefore, in such places where

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Apollo is represented as a god in person, I would use the former

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: interpretation; and where the effects of the sun are described, I would

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: make choice of the latter. Upon the whole, it will be necessary to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: avoid that perpetual repetition of the same epithets which we find in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Homer, and which, though it might be accommodated (as has been already

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: shown) to the ear of those times, is by no means so to ours: but one

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: may wait for opportunities of placing them, where they derive an

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: additional beauty from the occasions on which they are employed; and in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: doing this properly, a translator may at once show his fancy and his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: judgment.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: As for Homer’s repetitions, we may divide them into three sorts: of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: whole narrations and speeches, of single sentences, and of one verse or

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: hemistitch. I hope it is not impossible to have such a regard to these,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: as neither to lose so known a mark of the author on the one hand, nor

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: to offend the reader too much on the other. The repetition is not

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: ungraceful in those speeches, where the dignity of the speaker renders

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: it a sort of insolence to alter his words; as in the messages from gods

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: to men, or from higher powers to inferiors in concerns of state, or

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: where the ceremonial of religion seems to require it, in the solemn

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: forms of prayers, oaths, or the like. In other cases, I believe the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: best rule is, to be guided by the nearness, or distance, at which the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: repetitions are placed in the original: when they follow too close, one

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: may vary the expression; but it is a question, whether a professed

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: translator be authorized to omit any: if they be tedious, the author is

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: to answer for it.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: It only remains to speak of the versification. Homer (as has been said)

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: is perpetually applying the sound to the sense, and varying it on every

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: new subject. This is indeed one of the most exquisite beauties of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: poetry, and attainable by very few: I only know of Homer eminent for it

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: in the Greek, and Virgil in the Latin. I am sensible it is what may

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: sometimes happen by chance, when a writer is warm, and fully possessed

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of his image: however, it may reasonably be believed they designed

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: this, in whose verse it so manifestly appears in a superior degree to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: all others. Few readers have the ear to be judges of it: but those who

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: have, will see I have endeavoured at this beauty.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Upon the whole, I must confess myself utterly incapable of doing

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: justice to Homer. I attempt him in no other hope but that which one may

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: entertain without much vanity, of giving a more tolerable copy of him

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: than any entire translation in verse has yet done. We have only those

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of Chapman, Hobbes, and Ogilby. Chapman has taken the advantage of an

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: immeasurable length of verse, notwithstanding which, there is scarce

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: any paraphrase more loose and rambling than his. He has frequent

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: interpolations of four or six lines; and I remember one in the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: thirteenth book of the Odyssey, ver. 312, where he has spun twenty

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: verses out of two. He is often mistaken in so bold a manner, that one

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: might think he deviated on purpose, if he did not in other places of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: his notes insist so much upon verbal trifles. He appears to have had a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: strong affectation of extracting new meanings out of his author;

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: insomuch as to promise, in his rhyming preface, a poem of the mysteries

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: he had revealed in Homer; and perhaps he endeavoured to strain the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: obvious sense to this end. His expression is involved in fustian; a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: fault for which he was remarkable in his original writings, as in the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: tragedy of Bussy d’Amboise, &c. In a word, the nature of the man may

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: account for his whole performance; for he appears, from his preface and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: remarks, to have been of an arrogant turn, and an enthusiast in poetry.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: His own boast, of having finished half the Iliad in less than fifteen

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: weeks, shows with what negligence his version was performed. But that

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: which is to be allowed him, and which very much contributed to cover

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: his defects, is a daring fiery spirit that animates his translation,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: which is something like what one might imagine Homer himself would have

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: writ before he arrived at years of discretion.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Hobbes has given us a correct explanation of the sense in general; but

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: for particulars and circumstances he continually lops them, and often

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: omits the most beautiful. As for its being esteemed a close

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: translation, I doubt not many have been led into that error by the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: shortness of it, which proceeds not from his following the original

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: line by line, but from the contractions above mentioned. He sometimes

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: omits whole similes and sentences; and is now and then guilty of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: mistakes, into which no writer of his learning could have fallen, but

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: through carelessness. His poetry, as well as Ogilby’s, is too mean for

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: criticism.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: It is a great loss to the poetical world that Mr. Dryden did not live

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: to translate the Iliad. He has left us only the first book, and a small

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: part of the sixth; in which if he has in some places not truly

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: interpreted the sense, or preserved the antiquities, it ought to be

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: excused on account of the haste he was obliged to write in. He seems to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: have had too much regard to Chapman, whose words he sometimes copies,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: and has unhappily followed him in passages where he wanders from the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: original. However, had he translated the whole work, I would no more

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: have attempted Homer after him than Virgil: his version of whom

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: (notwithstanding some human errors) is the most noble and spirited

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: translation I know in any language. But the fate of great geniuses is

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: like that of great ministers: though they are confessedly the first in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the commonwealth of letters, they must be envied and calumniated only

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: for being at the head of it.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: That which, in my opinion, ought to be the endeavour of any one who

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: translates Homer, is above all things to keep alive that spirit and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: fire which makes his chief character: in particular places, where the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: sense can bear any doubt, to follow the strongest and most poetical, as

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: most agreeing with that character; to copy him in all the variations of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: his style, and the different modulations of his numbers; to preserve,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: in the more active or descriptive parts, a warmth and elevation; in the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: more sedate or narrative, a plainness and solemnity; in the speeches, a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: fulness and perspicuity; in the sentences, a shortness and gravity; not

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: to neglect even the little figures and turns on the words, nor

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: sometimes the very cast of the periods; neither to omit nor confound

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: any rites or customs of antiquity: perhaps too he ought to include the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: whole in a shorter compass than has hitherto been done by any

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: translator who has tolerably preserved either the sense or poetry. What

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: I would further recommend to him is, to study his author rather from

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: his own text, than from any commentaries, how learned soever, or

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: whatever figure they may make in the estimation of the world; to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: consider him attentively in comparison with Virgil above all the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: ancients, and with Milton above all the moderns. Next these, the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Archbishop of Cambray’s Telemachus may give him the truest idea of the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: spirit and turn of our author; and Bossu’s admirable Treatise of the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Epic Poem the justest notion of his design and conduct. But after all,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: with whatever judgment and study a man may proceed, or with whatever

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: happiness he may perform such a work, he must hope to please but a few;

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: those only who have at once a taste of poetry, and competent learning.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: For to satisfy such a want either, is not in the nature of this

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: undertaking; since a mere modern wit can like nothing that is not

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: modern, and a pedant nothing that is not Greek.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: What I have done is submitted to the public; from whose opinions I am

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: prepared to learn; though I fear no judges so little as our best poets,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: who are most sensible of the weight of this task. As for the worst,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: whatever they shall please to say, they may give me some concern as

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: they are unhappy men, but none as they are malignant writers. I was

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: guided in this translation by judgments very different from theirs, and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: by persons for whom they can have no kindness, if an old observation be

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: true, that the strongest antipathy in the world is that of fools to men

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of wit. Mr. Addison was the first whose advice determined me to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: undertake this task; who was pleased to write to me upon that occasion

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: in such terms as I cannot repeat without vanity. I was obliged to Sir

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Richard Steele for a very early recommendation of my undertaking to the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: public. Dr. Swift promoted my interest with that warmth with which he

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: always serves his friend. The humanity and frankness of Sir Samuel

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Garth are what I never knew wanting on any occasion. I must also

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: acknowledge, with infinite pleasure, the many friendly offices, as well

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: as sincere criticisms, of Mr. Congreve, who had led me the way in

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: translating some parts of Homer. I must add the names of Mr. Rowe, and

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Dr. Parnell, though I shall take a further opportunity of doing justice

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: to the last, whose good nature (to give it a great panegyric), is no

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: less extensive than his learning. The favour of these gentlemen is not

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: entirely undeserved by one who bears them so true an affection. But

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: what can I say of the honour so many of the great have done me; while

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the first names of the age appear as my subscribers, and the most

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: distinguished patrons and ornaments of learning as my chief

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: encouragers? Among these it is a particular pleasure to me to find,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: that my highest obligations are to such who have done most honour to

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the name of poet: that his grace the Duke of Buckingham was not

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: displeased I should undertake the author to whom he has given (in his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: excellent Essay), so complete a praise:

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: “Read Homer once, and you can read no more;

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: For all books else appear so mean, so poor,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Verse will seem prose: but still persist to read,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: And Homer will be all the books you need.”

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: That the Earl of Halifax was one of the first to favour me; of whom it

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: is hard to say whether the advancement of the polite arts is more owing

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: to his generosity or his example: that such a genius as my Lord

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Bolingbroke, not more distinguished in the great scenes of business,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: than in all the useful and entertaining parts of learning, has not

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: refused to be the critic of these sheets, and the patron of their

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: writer: and that the noble author of the tragedy of “Heroic Love” has

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: continued his partiality to me, from my writing pastorals to my

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: attempting the Iliad. I cannot deny myself the pride of confessing,

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: that I have had the advantage not only of their advice for the conduct

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: in general, but their correction of several particulars of this

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: translation.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: I could say a great deal of the pleasure of being distinguished by the

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Earl of Carnarvon; but it is almost absurd to particularize any one

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: generous action in a person whose whole life is a continued series of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: them. Mr. Stanhope, the present secretary of state, will pardon my

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: desire of having it known that he was pleased to promote this affair.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: The particular zeal of Mr. Harcourt (the son of the late Lord

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: Chancellor) gave me a proof how much I am honoured in a share of his

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: friendship. I must attribute to the same motive that of several others

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of my friends: to whom all acknowledgments are rendered unnecessary by

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the privileges of a familiar correspondence; and I am satisfied I can

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: no way better oblige men of their turn than by my silence.

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: In short, I have found more patrons than ever Homer wanted. He would

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: have thought himself happy to have met the same favour at Athens that

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: has been shown me by its learned rival, the University of Oxford. And I

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: can hardly envy him those pompous honours he received after death, when

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: I reflect on the enjoyment of so many agreeable obligations, and easy

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: friendships, which make the satisfaction of life. This distinction is

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: the more to be acknowledged, as it is shown to one whose pen has never

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: gratified the prejudices of particular parties, or the vanities of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: particular men. Whatever the success may prove, I shall never repent of

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: an undertaking in which I have experienced the candour and friendship

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: of so many persons of merit; and in which I hope to pass some of those

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: years of youth that are generally lost in a circle of follies, after a

Poem Title: POPE’S PREFACE TO THE ILIAD OF HOMER
line: manner neither wholly unuseful to others, nor disagreeable to myself.

line: In the war of Troy, the Greeks having sacked some of the neighbouring

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: towns, and taken from thence two beautiful captives, Chryseïs and

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Briseïs, allotted the first to Agamemnon, and the last to Achilles.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Chryses, the father of Chryseïs, and priest of Apollo, comes to the

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Grecian camp to ransom her; with which the action of the poem opens, in

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: the tenth year of the siege. The priest being refused, and insolently

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: dismissed by Agamemnon, entreats for vengeance from his god; who

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: inflicts a pestilence on the Greeks. Achilles calls a council, and

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: encourages Chalcas to declare the cause of it; who attributes it to the

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: refusal of Chryseïs. The king, being obliged to send back his captive,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: enters into a furious contest with Achilles, which Nestor pacifies;

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: however, as he had the absolute command of the army, he seizes on

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Briseïs in revenge. Achilles in discontent withdraws himself and his

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: forces from the rest of the Greeks; and complaining to Thetis, she

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: supplicates Jupiter to render them sensible of the wrong done to her

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: son, by giving victory to the Trojans. Jupiter, granting her suit,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: incenses Juno: between whom the debate runs high, till they are

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: reconciled by the address of Vulcan.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: The time of two-and-twenty days is taken up in this book: nine

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: during the plague, one in the council and quarrel of the princes,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: and twelve for Jupiter’s stay with the Æthiopians, at whose return

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Thetis prefers her petition. The scene lies in the Grecian camp,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: then changes to Chrysa, and lastly to Olympus.

line: Achilles’ wrath, to Greece the direful spring

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Of woes unnumber’d, heavenly goddess, sing!

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: That wrath which hurl’d to Pluto’s gloomy reign

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: The souls of mighty chiefs untimely slain;

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Whose limbs unburied on the naked shore,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Devouring dogs and hungry vultures tore.[41]

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Since great Achilles and Atrides strove,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Such was the sovereign doom, and such the will of Jove![42]

line: Declare, O Muse! in what ill-fated hour[43]

line: Sprung the fierce strife, from what offended power

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Latona’s son a dire contagion spread,[44]

line: And heap’d the camp with mountains of the dead;

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: The king of men his reverent priest defied,[45]

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And for the king’s offence the people died.

line: For Chryses sought with costly gifts to gain

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: His captive daughter from the victor’s chain.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Suppliant the venerable father stands;

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Apollo’s awful ensigns grace his hands:

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: By these he begs; and lowly bending down,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Extends the sceptre and the laurel crown.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: He sued to all, but chief implored for grace

line: The brother-kings, of Atreus’ royal race[46]

line: “Ye kings and warriors! may your vows be crown’d,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And Troy’s proud walls lie level with the ground.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: May Jove restore you when your toils are o’er

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Safe to the pleasures of your native shore.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: But, oh! relieve a wretched parent’s pain,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And give Chryseïs to these arms again;

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: If mercy fail, yet let my presents move,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And dread avenging Phœbus, son of Jove.”

THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: The Greeks in shouts their joint assent declare,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: The priest to reverence, and release the fair.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Not so Atrides; he, with kingly pride,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Repulsed the sacred sire, and thus replied:

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: “Hence on thy life, and fly these hostile plains,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Nor ask, presumptuous, what the king detains:

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Hence, with thy laurel crown, and golden rod,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Nor trust too far those ensigns of thy god.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Mine is thy daughter, priest, and shall remain;

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And prayers, and tears, and bribes, shall plead in vain;

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Till time shall rifle every youthful grace,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And age dismiss her from my cold embrace,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: In daily labours of the loom employ’d,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Or doom’d to deck the bed she once enjoy’d.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Hence then; to Argos shall the maid retire,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Far from her native soil and weeping sire.”

line: And in the anguish of a father mourn’d.

line: Disconsolate, not daring to complain,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Silent he wander’d by the sounding main;

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Till, safe at distance, to his god he prays,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: The god who darts around the world his rays.

line: “O Smintheus! sprung from fair Latona’s line,[47]

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Thou guardian power of Cilla the divine,[48]

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Thou source of light! whom Tenedos adores,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And whose bright presence gilds thy Chrysa’s shores.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: If e’er with wreaths I hung thy sacred fane,[49]

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Or fed the flames with fat of oxen slain;

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: God of the silver bow! thy shafts employ,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Avenge thy servant, and the Greeks destroy.”

THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Thus Chryses pray’d:—the favouring power attends,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And from Olympus’ lofty tops descends.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Bent was his bow, the Grecian hearts to wound;[50]

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Fierce as he moved, his silver shafts resound.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: Breathing revenge, a sudden night he spread,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And gloomy darkness roll’d about his head.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: The fleet in view, he twang’d his deadly bow,

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And hissing fly the feather’d fates below.

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: On mules and dogs the infection first began;[51]

Poem Title: THE CONTENTION OF ACHILLES AND AGAMEMNON.
line: And last, the vengeful arrows fix’d in man.

line: For nine long nights, through all the dusky air,

line: And round him deep the steely circle grows.

line: Of shouting huntsmen and of clamorous hounds;

line: And the red slaughter spreads on every side.

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.

line: Socus the brave, the generous, and the wise.

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: “O great Ulysses! much-enduring man!

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: Not deeper skill’d in every martial sleight,

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: Than worn to toils, and active in the fight!

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: This day two brothers shall thy conquest grace,

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: And end at once the great Hippasian race,

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: Or thou beneath this lance must press the field.”

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: He said, and forceful pierced his spacious shield:

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: Through the strong brass the ringing javelin thrown,

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: Plough’d half his side, and bared it to the bone.

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.

line: Stopp’d short of life, nor with his entrails mix’d.

line: The wound not mortal wise Ulysses knew,

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: Nor longer check my conquests on the foe;

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: But, pierced by this, to endless darkness go,

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: And add one spectre to the realms below!”

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: He spoke, while Socus, seized with sudden fright,

line: Trembling gave way, and turn’d his back to flight;

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: And held its passage through the panting heart:

line: Heaven owes Ulysses yet a longer date.

line: Ah, wretch! no father shall thy corpse compose;

line: Thy dying eyes no tender mother close;

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: And hovering vultures scream around their prey.

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: Me Greece shall honour, when I meet my doom,

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: With solemn funerals and a lasting tomb.”

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
line: Then raging with intolerable smart,

line: He writhes his body, and extracts the dart.

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.

line: And gladden’d Troy with sight of hostile blood.

line: Strong as he is, yet one opposed to all,

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.

line: And feel a loss not ages can repair.”

Poem Title: THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.
THE THIRD BATTLE, AND THE ACTS OF AGAMEMNON.

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: His eager arms around the goddess threw.

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Glad Earth perceives, and from her bosom pours

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Unbidden herbs and voluntary flowers:

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Thick new-born violets a soft carpet spread,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: And clustering lotos swell’d the rising bed,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: And sudden hyacinths the turf bestrow,[237]

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: And flamy crocus made the mountain glow

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: There golden clouds conceal the heavenly pair,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Steep’d in soft joys and circumfused with air;

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Celestial dews, descending o’er the ground,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Perfume the mount, and breathe ambrosia round:

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: At length, with love and sleep’s soft power oppress’d,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: The panting thunderer nods, and sinks to rest.

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Now to the navy borne on silent wings,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: To Neptune’s ear soft Sleep his message brings;

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Beside him sudden, unperceived, he stood,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: And thus with gentle words address’d the god:

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: “Now, Neptune! now, the important hour employ,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: To check a while the haughty hopes of Troy:

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: While Jove yet rests, while yet my vapours shed

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: The golden vision round his sacred head;

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: For Juno’s love, and Somnus’ pleasing ties,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Have closed those awful and eternal eyes.”

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Thus having said, the power of slumber flew,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: On human lids to drop the balmy dew.

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Neptune, with zeal increased, renews his care,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: And towering in the foremost ranks of war,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Indignant thus—“Oh once of martial fame!

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: O Greeks! if yet ye can deserve the name!

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: This half-recover’d day shall Troy obtain?

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Shall Hector thunder at your ships again?

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Lo! still he vaunts, and threats the fleet with fires,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: While stern Achilles in his wrath retires.

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: One hero’s loss too tamely you deplore,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Be still yourselves, and ye shall need no more.

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Oh yet, if glory any bosom warms,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Brace on your firmest helms, and stand to arms:

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: His strongest spear each valiant Grecian wield,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Each valiant Grecian seize his broadest shield;

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Let to the weak the lighter arms belong,

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: The ponderous targe be wielded by the strong.

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Thus arm’d, not Hector shall our presence stay;

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
line: Myself, ye Greeks! myself will lead the way.”

Poem Title: JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
JUNO DECEIVES JUPITER BY THE GIRDLE OF VENUS.
