Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Those, though the swiftest, by some god withheld,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Lie sure disabled in the middle field:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For, since the goal they doubled, round the plain

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: I search to find them, but I search in vain.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Perchance the reins forsook the driver’s hand,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And, turn’d too short, he tumbled on the strand,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Shot from the chariot; while his coursers stray

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With frantic fury from the destined way.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Rise then some other, and inform my sight,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For these dim eyes, perhaps, discern not right;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Yet sure he seems, to judge by shape and air,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The great Ætolian chief, renown’d in war.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Old man! (Oïleus rashly thus replies)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Thy tongue too hastily confers the prize;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Of those who view the course, nor sharpest eyed,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Nor youngest, yet the readiest to decide.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Eumelus’ steeds, high bounding in the chase,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Still, as at first, unrivall’d lead the race:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: I well discern him, as he shakes the rein,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And hear his shouts victorious o’er the plain.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Thus he. Idomeneus, incensed, rejoin’d:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Barbarous of words! and arrogant of mind!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Contentious prince, of all the Greeks beside

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The last in merit, as the first in pride!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To vile reproach what answer can we make?

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A goblet or a tripod let us stake,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And be the king the judge. The most unwise

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Will learn their rashness, when they pay the price.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He said: and Ajax, by mad passion borne,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Stern had replied; fierce scorn enhancing scorn

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To fell extremes. But Thetis’ godlike son

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Awful amidst them rose, and thus begun:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Forbear, ye chiefs! reproachful to contend;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Much would ye blame, should others thus offend:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And lo! the approaching steeds your contest end.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: No sooner had he spoke, but thundering near,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Drives, through a stream of dust, the charioteer.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: High o’er his head the circling lash he wields:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His bounding horses scarcely touch the fields:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His car amidst the dusty whirlwind roll’d,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Bright with the mingled blaze of tin and gold,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Refulgent through the cloud: no eye could find

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The track his flying wheels had left behind:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And the fierce coursers urged their rapid pace

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: So swift, it seem’d a flight, and not a race.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Now victor at the goal Tydides stands,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Quits his bright car, and springs upon the sands;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: From the hot steeds the sweaty torrents stream;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The well-plied whip is hung athwart the beam:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With joy brave Sthenelus receives the prize,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The tripod-vase, and dame with radiant eyes:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: These to the ships his train triumphant leads,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The chief himself unyokes the panting steeds.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Young Nestor follows (who by art, not force,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: O’erpass’d Atrides) second in the course.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Behind, Atrides urged the race, more near

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Than to the courser in his swift career

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The following car, just touching with his heel

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And brushing with his tail the whirling wheel:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Such, and so narrow now the space between

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The rivals, late so distant on the green;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: So soon swift Æthe her lost ground regain’d,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: One length, one moment, had the race obtain’d.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Merion pursued, at greater distance still,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With tardier coursers, and inferior skill.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Last came, Admetus! thy unhappy son;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Slow dragged the steeds his batter’d chariot on:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Achilles saw, and pitying thus begun:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Behold! the man whose matchless art surpass’d

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The sons of Greece! the ablest, yet the last!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Fortune denies, but justice bids us pay

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (Since great Tydides bears the first away)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To him the second honours of the day.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The Greeks consent with loud-applauding cries,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And then Eumelus had received the prize,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: But youthful Nestor, jealous of his fame,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The award opposes, and asserts his claim.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Think not (he cries) I tamely will resign,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: O Peleus’ son! the mare so justly mine.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: What if the gods, the skilful to confound,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Have thrown the horse and horseman to the ground?

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Perhaps he sought not heaven by sacrifice,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And vows omitted forfeited the prize.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: If yet (distinction to thy friend to show,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And please a soul desirous to bestow)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Some gift must grace Eumelus, view thy store

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Of beauteous handmaids, steeds, and shining ore;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: An ample present let him thence receive,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And Greece shall praise thy generous thirst to give.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: But this my prize I never shall forego;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: This, who but touches, warriors! is my foe.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Thus spake the youth; nor did his words offend;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Pleased with the well-turn’d flattery of a friend,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Achilles smiled: “The gift proposed (he cried),

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Antilochus! we shall ourself provide.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With plates of brass the corslet cover’d o’er,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (The same renown’d Asteropaeus wore,)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Whose glittering margins raised with silver shine,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (No vulgar gift,) Eumelus! shall be thine.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He said: Automedon at his command

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The corslet brought, and gave it to his hand.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Distinguish’d by his friend, his bosom glows

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With generous joy: then Menelaus rose;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The herald placed the sceptre in his hands,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And still’d the clamour of the shouting bands.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Not without cause incensed at Nestor’s son,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And inly grieving, thus the king begun:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “The praise of wisdom, in thy youth obtain’d,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: An act so rash, Antilochus! has stain’d.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Robb’d of my glory and my just reward,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To you, O Grecians! be my wrong declared:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: So not a leader shall our conduct blame,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Or judge me envious of a rival’s fame.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: But shall not we, ourselves, the truth maintain?

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: What needs appealing in a fact so plain?

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: What Greek shall blame me, if I bid thee rise,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And vindicate by oath th’ ill-gotten prize?

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Rise if thou darest, before thy chariot stand,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The driving scourge high-lifted in thy hand;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And touch thy steeds, and swear thy whole intent

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Was but to conquer, not to circumvent.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Swear by that god whose liquid arms surround

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The globe, and whose dread earthquakes heave the ground!”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The prudent chief with calm attention heard;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Then mildly thus: “Excuse, if youth have err’d;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Superior as thou art, forgive the offence,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Nor I thy equal, or in years, or sense.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Thou know’st the errors of unripen’d age,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Weak are its counsels, headlong is its rage.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The prize I quit, if thou thy wrath resign;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The mare, or aught thou ask’st, be freely thine

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ere I become (from thy dear friendship torn)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Hateful to thee, and to the gods forsworn.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: So spoke Antilochus; and at the word

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The mare contested to the king restored.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Joy swells his soul: as when the vernal grain

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Lifts the green ear above the springing plain,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The fields their vegetable life renew,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And laugh and glitter with the morning dew;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Such joy the Spartan’s shining face o’erspread,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And lifted his gay heart, while thus he said:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Still may our souls, O generous youth! agree

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: ’Tis now Atrides’ turn to yield to thee.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Rash heat perhaps a moment might control,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Not break, the settled temper of thy soul.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Not but (my friend) ’tis still the wiser way

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To waive contention with superior sway;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For ah! how few, who should like thee offend,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Like thee, have talents to regain the friend!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To plead indulgence, and thy fault atone,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Suffice thy father’s merit and thy own:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Generous alike, for me, the sire and son

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Have greatly suffer’d, and have greatly done.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: I yield; that all may know, my soul can bend,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Nor is my pride preferr’d before my friend.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He said; and pleased his passion to command,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Resign’d the courser to Noemon’s hand,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Friend of the youthful chief: himself content,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The shining charger to his vessel sent.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The golden talents Merion next obtain’d;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The fifth reward, the double bowl, remain’d.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Achilles this to reverend Nestor bears.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And thus the purpose of his gift declares:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Accept thou this, O sacred sire! (he said)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: In dear memorial of Patroclus dead;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Dead and for ever lost Patroclus lies,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For ever snatch’d from our desiring eyes!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Take thou this token of a grateful heart,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Though ’tis not thine to hurl the distant dart,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The quoit to toss, the ponderous mace to wield,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Or urge the race, or wrestle on the field:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Thy pristine vigour age has overthrown,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: But left the glory of the past thy own.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He said, and placed the goblet at his side;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With joy the venerable king replied:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Wisely and well, my son, thy words have proved

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A senior honour’d, and a friend beloved!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Too true it is, deserted of my strength,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: These wither’d arms and limbs have fail’d at length.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Oh! had I now that force I felt of yore,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Known through Buprasium and the Pylian shore!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Victorious then in every solemn game,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ordain’d to Amarynces’ mighty name;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The brave Epeians gave my glory way,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ætolians, Pylians, all resign’d the day.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: I quell’d Clytomedes in fights of hand,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And backward hurl’d Ancæus on the sand,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Surpass’d Iphyclus in the swift career,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Phyleus and Polydorus with the spear.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The sons of Actor won the prize of horse,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: But won by numbers, not by art or force:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For the famed twins, impatient to survey

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Prize after prize by Nestor borne away,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Sprung to their car; and with united pains

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: One lash’d the coursers, while one ruled the reins.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Such once I was! Now to these tasks succeeds

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A younger race, that emulate our deeds:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: I yield, alas! (to age who must not yield?)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Though once the foremost hero of the field.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Go thou, my son! by generous friendship led,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With martial honours decorate the dead:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: While pleased I take the gift thy hands present,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (Pledge of benevolence, and kind intent,)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Rejoiced, of all the numerous Greeks, to see

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Not one but honours sacred age and me:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Those due distinctions thou so well canst pay,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: May the just gods return another day!”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Proud of the gift, thus spake the full of days:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Achilles heard him, prouder of the praise.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The prizes next are order’d to the field,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For the bold champions who the caestus wield.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A stately mule, as yet by toils unbroke,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Of six years’ age, unconscious of the yoke,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Is to the circus led, and firmly bound;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Next stands a goblet, massy, large, and round.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Achilles rising, thus: “Let Greece excite

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Two heroes equal to this hardy fight;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Who dare the foe with lifted arms provoke,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And rush beneath the long-descending stroke.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: On whom Apollo shall the palm bestow,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And whom the Greeks supreme by conquest know,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: This mule his dauntless labours shall repay,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The vanquish’d bear the massy bowl away.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: This dreadful combat great Epeüs chose;[291]

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: High o’er the crowd, enormous bulk! he rose,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And seized the beast, and thus began to say:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Stand forth some man, to bear the bowl away!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (Price of his ruin: for who dares deny

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: This mule my right; the undoubted victor I)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Others, ’tis own’d, in fields of battle shine,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: But the first honours of this fight are mine;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For who excels in all? Then let my foe

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Draw near, but first his certain fortune know;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Secure this hand shall his whole frame confound,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Mash all his bones, and all his body pound:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: So let his friends be nigh, a needful train,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To heave the batter’d carcase off the plain.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The giant spoke; and in a stupid gaze

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The host beheld him, silent with amaze!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: ’Twas thou, Euryalus! who durst aspire

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To meet his might, and emulate thy sire,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The great Mecistheus; who in days of yore

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: In Theban games the noblest trophy bore,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (The games ordain’d dead OEdipus to grace,)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And singly vanquish the Cadmean race.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Him great Tydides urges to contend,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Warm with the hopes of conquest for his friend;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Officious with the cincture girds him round;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And to his wrist the gloves of death are bound.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Amid the circle now each champion stands,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And poises high in air his iron hands;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With clashing gauntlets now they fiercely close,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Their crackling jaws re-echo to the blows,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And painful sweat from all their members flows.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: At length Epeus dealt a weighty blow

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Full on the cheek of his unwary foe;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Beneath that ponderous arm’s resistless sway

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Down dropp’d he, nerveless, and extended lay.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: As a large fish, when winds and waters roar,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: By some huge billow dash’d against the shore,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Lies panting; not less batter’d with his wound,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The bleeding hero pants upon the ground.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To rear his fallen foe, the victor lends,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Scornful, his hand; and gives him to his friends;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Whose arms support him, reeling through the throng,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And dragging his disabled legs along;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Nodding, his head hangs down his shoulder o’er;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His mouth and nostrils pour the clotted gore;[292]

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Wrapp’d round in mists he lies, and lost to thought;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His friends receive the bowl, too dearly bought.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The third bold game Achilles next demands,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And calls the wrestlers to the level sands:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A massy tripod for the victor lies,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Of twice six oxen its reputed price;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And next, the loser’s spirits to restore,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A female captive, valued but at four.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Scarce did the chief the vigorous strife propose

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: When tower-like Ajax and Ulysses rose.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Amid the ring each nervous rival stands,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Embracing rigid with implicit hands.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Close lock’d above, their heads and arms are mix’d:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Below, their planted feet at distance fix’d;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Like two strong rafters which the builder forms,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Proof to the wintry winds and howling storms,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Their tops connected, but at wider space

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Fix’d on the centre stands their solid base.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Now to the grasp each manly body bends;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The humid sweat from every pore descends;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Their bones resound with blows: sides, shoulders, thighs

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Swell to each gripe, and bloody tumours rise.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Nor could Ulysses, for his art renown’d,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: O’erturn the strength of Ajax on the ground;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Nor could the strength of Ajax overthrow

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The watchful caution of his artful foe.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: While the long strife even tired the lookers on,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Thus to Ulysses spoke great Telamon:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Or let me lift thee, chief, or lift thou me:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Prove we our force, and Jove the rest decree.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He said; and, straining, heaved him off the ground

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With matchless strength; that time Ulysses found

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The strength to evade, and where the nerves combine

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His ankle struck: the giant fell supine;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ulysses, following, on his bosom lies;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Shouts of applause run rattling through the skies.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ajax to lift Ulysses next essays;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He barely stirr’d him, but he could not raise:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His knee lock’d fast, the foe’s attempt denied;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And grappling close, they tumbled side by side.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Defiled with honourable dust they roll,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Still breathing strife, and unsubdued of soul:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Again they rage, again to combat rise;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: When great Achilles thus divides the prize:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Your noble vigour, O my friends, restrain;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Nor weary out your generous strength in vain.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ye both have won: let others who excel,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Now prove that prowess you have proved so well.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The hero’s words the willing chiefs obey,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: From their tired bodies wipe the dust away,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And, clothed anew, the following games survey.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And now succeed the gifts ordain’d to grace

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The youths contending in the rapid race:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A silver urn that full six measures held,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: By none in weight or workmanship excell’d:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Sidonian artists taught the frame to shine,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Elaborate, with artifice divine;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Whence Tyrian sailors did the prize transport,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And gave to Thoas at the Lemnian port:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: From him descended, good Eunaeus heir’d

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The glorious gift; and, for Lycaon spared,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To brave Patroclus gave the rich reward:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Now, the same hero’s funeral rites to grace,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: It stands the prize of swiftness in the race.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A well-fed ox was for the second placed;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And half a talent must content the last.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Achilles rising then bespoke the train:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Who hope the palm of swiftness to obtain,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Stand forth, and bear these prizes from the plain.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The hero said, and starting from his place,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Oilean Ajax rises to the race;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ulysses next; and he whose speed surpass’d

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His youthful equals, Nestor’s son, the last.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ranged in a line the ready racers stand;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Pelides points the barrier with his hand;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: All start at once; Oïleus led the race;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The next Ulysses, measuring pace with pace;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Behind him, diligently close, he sped,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: As closely following as the running thread

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The spindle follows, and displays the charms

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Of the fair spinster’s breast and moving arms:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Graceful in motion thus, his foe he plies,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And treads each footstep ere the dust can rise;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His glowing breath upon his shoulders plays:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The admiring Greeks loud acclamations raise:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To him they give their wishes, hearts, and eyes,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And send their souls before him as he flies.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Now three times turn’d in prospect of the goal,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The panting chief to Pallas lifts his soul:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Assist, O goddess!” thus in thought he pray’d!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And present at his thought descends the maid.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Buoy’d by her heavenly force, he seems to swim,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And feels a pinion lifting every limb.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: All fierce, and ready now the prize to gain,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Unhappy Ajax stumbles on the plain

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (O’erturn’d by Pallas), where the slippery shore

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Was clogg’d with slimy dung and mingled gore.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (The self-same place beside Patroclus’ pyre,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Where late the slaughter’d victims fed the fire.)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Besmear’d with filth, and blotted o’er with clay,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Obscene to sight, the rueful racer lay;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The well-fed bull (the second prize) he shared,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And left the urn Ulysses’ rich reward.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Then, grasping by the horn the mighty beast,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The baffled hero thus the Greeks address’d:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Accursed fate! the conquest I forego;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A mortal I, a goddess was my foe;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: She urged her favourite on the rapid way,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And Pallas, not Ulysses, won the day.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Thus sourly wail’d he, sputtering dirt and gore;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A burst of laughter echoed through the shore.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Antilochus, more humorous than the rest,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Takes the last prize, and takes it with a jest:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Why with our wiser elders should we strive?

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The gods still love them, and they always thrive.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ye see, to Ajax I must yield the prize:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He to Ulysses, still more aged and wise;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (A green old age unconscious of decays,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: That proves the hero born in better days!)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Behold his vigour in this active race!

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Achilles only boasts a swifter pace:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For who can match Achilles? He who can,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Must yet be more than hero, more than man.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The effect succeeds the speech. Pelides cries,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Thy artful praise deserves a better prize.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Nor Greece in vain shall hear thy friend extoll’d;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Receive a talent of the purest gold.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The youth departs content. The host admire

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The son of Nestor, worthy of his sire.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Next these a buckler, spear, and helm, he brings;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Cast on the plain, the brazen burden rings:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Arms which of late divine Sarpedon wore,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And great Patroclus in short triumph bore.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Stand forth the bravest of our host! (he cries)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Whoever dares deserve so rich a prize,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Now grace the lists before our army’s sight,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And sheathed in steel, provoke his foe to fight.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Who first the jointed armour shall explore,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And stain his rival’s mail with issuing gore,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The sword Asteropaeus possess’d of old,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: (A Thracian blade, distinct with studs of gold,)

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Shall pay the stroke, and grace the striker’s side:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: These arms in common let the chiefs divide:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For each brave champion, when the combat ends,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A sumptuous banquet at our tents attends.”

FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Fierce at the word uprose great Tydeus’ son,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And the huge bulk of Ajax Telamon.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Clad in refulgent steel, on either hand,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The dreadful chiefs amid the circle stand;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Louring they meet, tremendous to the sight;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Each Argive bosom beats with fierce delight.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Opposed in arms not long they idly stood,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: But thrice they closed, and thrice the charge renew’d.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A furious pass the spear of Ajax made

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Through the broad shield, but at the corslet stay’d.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Not thus the foe: his javelin aim’d above

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The buckler’s margin, at the neck he drove.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: But Greece, now trembling for her hero’s life,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Bade share the honours, and surcease the strife.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Yet still the victor’s due Tydides gains,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With him the sword and studded belt remains.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Then hurl’d the hero, thundering on the ground,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: A mass of iron (an enormous round),

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Whose weight and size the circling Greeks admire,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Rude from the furnace, and but shaped by fire.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: This mighty quoit Aëtion wont to rear,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And from his whirling arm dismiss in air;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The giant by Achilles slain, he stow’d

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Among his spoils this memorable load.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For this, he bids those nervous artists vie,

line: That teach the disk to sound along the sky.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Let him, whose might can hurl this bowl, arise;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Who farthest hurls it, take it as his prize;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: If he be one enrich’d with large domain

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Of downs for flocks, and arable for grain,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Small stock of iron needs that man provide;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His hinds and swains whole years shall be supplied

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: From hence; nor ask the neighbouring city’s aid

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For ploughshares, wheels, and all the rural trade.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Stern Polypœtes stepp’d before the throng,

line: And great Leonteus, more than mortal strong;

line: Whose force with rival forces to oppose,

line: Uprose great Ajax; up Epeus rose.

line: Each stood in order: first Epeus threw;

line: High o’er the wondering crowds the whirling circle flew.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Leonteus next a little space surpass’d;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And third, the strength of godlike Ajax cast.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: O’er both their marks it flew; till fiercely flung

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: From Polypœtes’ arm the discus sung:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Far as a swain his whirling sheephook throws,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: That distant falls among the grazing cows,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: So past them all the rapid circle flies:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: His friends, while loud applauses shake the skies,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With force conjoin’d heave off the weighty prize.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Those, who in skilful archery contend,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He next invites the twanging bow to bend;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And twice ten axes casts amidst the round,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Ten double-edged, and ten that singly wound

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The mast, which late a first-rate galley bore,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The hero fixes in the sandy shore;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To the tall top a milk-white dove they tie,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The trembling mark at which their arrows fly.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Whose weapon strikes yon fluttering bird, shall bear

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: These two-edged axes, terrible in war;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The single, he whose shaft divides the cord.”

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He said: experienced Merion took the word;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And skilful Teucer: in the helm they threw

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Their lots inscribed, and forth the latter flew.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Swift from the string the sounding arrow flies;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: But flies unbless’d! No grateful sacrifice,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: No firstling lambs, unheedful! didst thou vow

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To Phœbus, patron of the shaft and bow.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: For this, thy well-aim’d arrow turn’d aside,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Err’d from the dove, yet cut the cord that tied:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Adown the mainmast fell the parted string,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And the free bird to heaven displays her wing:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Sea, shores, and skies, with loud applause resound,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And Merion eager meditates the wound:

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: He takes the bow, directs the shaft above,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And following with his eye the soaring dove,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Implores the god to speed it through the skies,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With vows of firstling lambs, and grateful sacrifice,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The dove, in airy circles as she wheels,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Amid the clouds the piercing arrow feels;

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: Quite through and through the point its passage found,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: And at his feet fell bloody to the ground.

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: The wounded bird, ere yet she breathed her last,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: With flagging wings alighted on the mast,

line: From the pleased crowd new peals of thunder rise,

line: And to the ships brave Merion bears the prize.

FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: To close the funeral games, Achilles last

line: A massy spear amid the circle placed,

line: And ample charger of unsullied frame,

line: With flowers high-wrought, not blacken’d yet by flame.

line: For these he bids the heroes prove their art,

line: Whose dexterous skill directs the flying dart.

line: Here too great Merion hopes the noble prize;

line: Nor here disdain’d the king of men to rise.

line: With joy Pelides saw the honour paid,

line: Rose to the monarch, and respectful said:

FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: “Thee first in virtue, as in power supreme,

Poem Title: FUNERAL GAMES IN HONOUR OF PATROCLUS.[280]
line: O king of nations! all thy Greeks proclaim;

line: In every martial game thy worth attest,

line: And know thee both their greatest and their best.

line: Take then the prize, but let brave Merion bear

line: We have now passed through the Iliad, and seen the anger of Achilles,

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: and the terrible effects of it, at an end: as that only was the subject

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: of the poem, and the nature of epic poetry would not permit our author

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: to proceed to the event of the war, it perhaps may be acceptable to the

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: common reader to give a short account of what happened to Troy and the

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: chief actors in this poem after the conclusion of it.

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: I need not mention that Troy was taken soon after the death of Hector

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: by the stratagem of the wooden horse, the particulars of which are

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: described by Virgil in the second book of the Æneid.

line: Achilles fell before Troy, by the hand of Paris, by the shot of an

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: arrow in his heel, as Hector had prophesied at his death, lib. xxii.

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: The unfortunate Priam was killed by Pyrrhus, the son of Achilles.

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: Ajax, after the death of Achilles, had a contest with Ulysses for the

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: armour of Vulcan, but being defeated in his aim, he slew himself

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: through indignation.

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: Helen, after the death of Paris, married Deiphobus his brother, and at

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: the taking of Troy betrayed him, in order to reconcile herself to

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: Menelaus her first husband, who received her again into favour.

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: Agamemnon at his return was barbarously murdered by Ægysthus, at the

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: instigation of Clytemnestra his wife, who in his absence had

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: dishonoured his bed with Ægysthus.

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: Diomed, after the fall of Troy, was expelled his own country, and

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: scarce escaped with his life from his adulterous wife Ægialé; but at

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: last was received by Daunus in Apulia, and shared his kingdom; it is

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: uncertain how he died.

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: Nestor lived in peace with his children, in Pylos, his native country.

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: Ulysses also, after innumerable troubles by sea and land, at last

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: returned in safety to Ithaca, which is the subject of Homer’s Odyssey.

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: For what remains, I beg to be excused from the ceremonies of taking

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: leave at the end of my work, and from embarrassing myself, or others,

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: with any defences or apologies about it. But instead of endeavouring to

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: raise a vain monument to myself, of the merits or difficulties of it

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: (which must be left to the world, to truth, and to posterity), let me

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: leave behind me a memorial of my friendship with one of the most

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: valuable of men, as well as finest writers, of my age and country, one

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: who has tried, and knows by his own experience, how hard an undertaking

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: it is to do justice to Homer, and one whom (I am sure) sincerely

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: rejoices with me at the period of my labours. To him, therefore, having

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: brought this long work to a conclusion, I desire to dedicate it, and to

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: have the honour and satisfaction of placing together, in this manner,

Poem Title: CONCLUDING NOTE.
line: the names of Mr. CONGREVE, and of

[11] It was at Bolissus, and in the house of this Chian citizen, that
Homer is said to have written the Batrachomyomachia, or Battle of the
Frogs and Mice, the Epicichlidia, and some other minor works.
[12] Chandler, Travels, vol. i. p. 61, referred to in the Voyage
Pittoresque dans la Grèce, vol. i. P. 92, where a view of the spot is
given of which the author candidly says,— “Je ne puis répondre d’une
exactitude scrupuleuse dans la vue générale que j’en donne, car étant
allé seul pour l’examiner je perdis mon crayon, et je fus obligé de
m’en fier à ma mémoire. Je ne crois cependant pas avoir trop à me
plaindre d’elle en cette occasion.”
[13] A more probable reason for this companionship, and for the
character of Mentor itself, is given by the allegorists, viz.: the
assumption of Mentor’s form by the guardian deity of the wise Ulysses,
Minerva. The classical reader may compare Plutarch, Opp. t. ii. p.
880; _Xyland_. Heraclid. Pont. Alleg. Hom. p. 531-5, of Gale’s Opusc.
Mythol. Dionys. Halic. de Hom. Poes. c. 15; Apul. de Deo Socrat. s. f.
[15] The riddle is given in Section 35. Compare Mackenzie’s note, p.
xxx.
[16] Heeren’s Ancient Greece, p. 96.
[17] Compare Sir E. L. Bulwer’s Caxtons v. i. p. 4.
[18] Pericles and Aspasia, Letter lxxxiv., Works, vol ii. p. 387.
[19] Quarterly Review, No. lxxxvii., p. 147.
[20] Viz., the following beautiful passage, for the translation of
which I am indebted to Coleridge, Classic Poets, p. 286.
“Origias, farewell! and oh! remember me
Hereafter, when some stranger from the sea,
A hapless wanderer, may your isle explore,
And ask you, maid, of all the bards you boast,
Who sings the sweetest, and delights you most
Oh! answer all,—‘A blind old man and poor
Sweetest he sings—and dwells on Chios’ rocky shore.’”
_See_ Thucyd. iii, 104.
[21] Longin., de Sublim., ix. § 26. Ὅθεν ἐν τῇ Ὀδυσσείᾳ παρεικάσαι τις
ἂν καταδυομένῳ τὸν Ὅμηρον ἡλίῳ, οδ δίχα τῆς σφοδρότητος παραμένει το
μέγεθος.
[22] See Tatian, quoted in Fabric. Bibl. Gr. v. II t. ii. Mr.
Mackenzie has given three brief but elaborate papers on the different
writers on the subject, which deserve to be consulted. See Notes and
Queries, vol. v. pp. 99, 171, and 221. His own views are moderate, and
perhaps as satisfactory, on the whole, as any of the hypotheses
hitherto put forth. In fact, they consist in an attempt to blend those
hypotheses into something like consistency, rather than in advocating
any individual theory.
[23] Letters to Phileleuth; Lips.
[24] Hist. of Greece, vol. ii. p. 191, sqq.
[25] It is, indeed not easy to calculate the height to which the
memory may be cultivated. To take an ordinary case, we might refer to
that of any first rate actor, who must be prepared, at a very short
warning, to ‘rhapsodize,’ night after night, parts which when laid
together, would amount to an immense number of lines. But all this is
nothing to two instances of our own day. Visiting at Naples a
gentleman of the highest intellectual attainments, and who held a
distinguished rank among the men of letters in the last century, he
informed us that the day before he had passed much time in examining a
man, not highly educated, who had learned to repeat the whole
Gierusalemme of Tasso, not only to recite it consecutively, but also
to repeat those stanzas in utter defiance of the sense, either
forwards or backwards, or from the eighth line to the first,
alternately the odd and even lines—in short, whatever the passage
required; the memory, which seemed to cling to the words much more
than to the sense, had it at such perfect command, that it could
produce it under any form. Our informant went on to state that this
singular being was proceeding to learn the Orlando Furioso in the same
manner. But even this instance is less wonderful than one as to which
we may appeal to any of our readers that happened some twenty years
ago to visit the town of Stirling, in Scotland. No such person can
have forgotten the poor, uneducated man Blind Jamie who could actually
repeat, after a few minutes consideration any verse required from any
part of the Bible—even the obscurest and most unimportant enumeration
of mere proper names not excepted. We do not mention these facts as
touching the more difficult part of the question before us, but facts
they are; and if we find so much difficulty in calculating the extent
to which the mere memory may be cultivated, are we, in these days of
multifarious reading, and of countless distracting affairs, fair
judges of the perfection to which the invention and the memory
combined may attain in a simpler age, and among a more single minded
people?—Quarterly Review, _l. c._, p. 143, sqq.
Heeren steers between the two opinions, observing that, “The
Dschungariade of the Calmucks is said to surpass the poems of Homer
in length, as much as it stands beneath them in merit, and yet it
exists only in the memory of a people which is not unacquainted
with writing. But the songs of a nation are probably the last
things which are committed to writing, for the very reason that
they are remembered.”— _Ancient Greece_. p. 100.
[26] Vol. II p. 198, sqq.
[27] Quarterly Review, _l. c._, p. 131 sq.
[28] Betrachtungen über die Ilias. Berol. 1841. See Grote, p. 204.
Notes and Queries, vol. v. p. 221.
[29] Prolegg. pp. xxxii., xxxvi., &c.
[30] Vol. ii. p. 214 sqq.
[31] “Who,” says Cicero, de Orat. iii. 34, “was more learned in that
age, or whose eloquence is reported to have been more perfected by
literature than that of Peisistratus, who is said first to have
disposed the books of Homer in the order in which we now have them?”
Compare Wolf’s Prolegomena 33, §.
[32] “The first book, together with the eighth, and the books from the
eleventh to the twenty-second inclusive, seems to form the primary
organization of the poem, then properly an Achilleïs.”—Grote, vol. ii.
[33] K. R. H. Mackenzie, Notes and Queries, p. 222 sqq.
[34] See his Epistle to Raphelingius, in Schroeder’s edition, 4to.,
Delphis, 1728.
[35] Ancient Greece, p. 101.
[36] The best description of this monument will be found in Vaux’s
“Antiquities of the British Museum,” p. 198 sq. The monument itself
(Towneley Sculptures, No. 123) is well known.
[37] Coleridge, Classic Poets, p. 276.
[38] Preface to her Homer.
[39] Hesiod. Opp. et Dier. Lib. I. vers. 155, &c.
[40] The following argument of the Iliad, corrected in a few
particulars, is translated from Bitaubé, and is, perhaps, the neatest
summary that has ever been drawn up:—“A hero, injured by his general,
and animated with a noble resentment, retires to his tent; and for a
season withdraws himself and his troops from the war. During this
interval, victory abandons the army, which for nine years has been
occupied in a great enterprise, upon the successful termination of
which the honour of their country depends. The general, at length
opening his eyes to the fault which he had committed, deputes the
principal officers of his army to the incensed hero, with commission
to make compensation for the injury, and to tender magnificent
presents. The hero, according to the proud obstinacy of his character,
persists in his animosity; the army is again defeated, and is on the
verge of entire destruction. This inexorable man has a friend; this
friend weeps before him, and asks for the hero’s arms, and for
permission to go to the war in his stead. The eloquence of friendship
prevails more than the intercession of the ambassadors or the gifts of
the general. He lends his armour to his friend, but commands him not
to engage with the chief of the enemy’s army, because he reserves to
himself the honour of that combat, and because he also fears for his
friend’s life. The prohibition is forgotten; the friend listens to
nothing but his courage; his corpse is brought back to the hero, and
the hero’s arms become the prize of the conqueror. Then the hero,
given up to the most lively despair, prepares to fight; he receives
from a divinity new armour, is reconciled with his general and,
thirsting for glory and revenge, enacts prodigies of valour, recovers
the victory, slays the enemy’s chief, honours his friend with superb
funeral rites, and exercises a cruel vengeance on the body of his
destroyer; but finally appeased by the tears and prayers of the father
of the slain warrior, restores to the old man the corpse of his son,
which he buries with due solemnities.’—Coleridge, p. 177, sqq.
[41] Vultures: Pope is more accurate than the poet he translates, for
Homer writes “a prey to dogs and to _all_ kinds of birds. But all
kinds of birds are not carnivorous.
[42] _i.e._ during the whole time of their striving the will of Jove
was being gradually accomplished.
[43] Compare Milton’s “Paradise Lost” i. 6
“Sing, heavenly Muse, that on the secret top
Of Horeb, or of Sinai, didst inspire
That shepherd.”
[44] _Latona’s son: i.e._ Apollo.
[45] _King of men:_ Agamemnon.
[46] _Brother kings:_ Menelaus and Agamemnon.
[47] _Smintheus_ an epithet taken from sminthos, the Phrygian name
for a _mouse_, was applied to Apollo for having put an end to a plague
of mice which had harassed that territory. Strabo, however, says, that
when the Teucri were migrating from Crete, they were told by an oracle
to settle in that place, where they should not be attacked by the
original inhabitants of the land, and that, having halted for the
night, a number of field-mice came and gnawed away the leathern straps
of their baggage, and thongs of their armour. In fulfilment of the
oracle, they settled on the spot, and raised a temple to Sminthean
Apollo. Grote, “History of Greece,” i. p. 68, remarks that the
“worship of Sminthean Apollo, in various parts of the Troad and its
neighboring territory, dates before the earliest period of Æolian
colonization.”
[48] _Cilla_, a town of Troas near Thebe, so called from Cillus, a
sister of Hippodamia, slain by Œnomaus.
[49] A mistake. It should be,
“If e’er I roofed thy graceful fane,”
for the custom of decorating temples with garlands was of later date.
[50] _Bent was his bow_ “The Apollo of Homer, it must be borne in
mind, is a different character from the deity of the same name in the
later classical pantheon. Throughout both poems, all deaths from
unforeseen or invisible causes, the ravages of pestilence, the fate of
the young child or promising adult, cut off in the germ of infancy or
flower of youth, of the old man dropping peacefully into the grave, or
of the reckless sinner suddenly checked in his career of crime, are
ascribed to the arrows of Apollo or Diana. The oracular functions of
the god rose naturally out of the above fundamental attributes, for
who could more appropriately impart to mortals what little
foreknowledge Fate permitted of her decrees than the agent of her most
awful dispensations? The close union of the arts of prophecy and song
explains his additional office of god of music, while the arrows with
which he and his sister were armed, symbols of sudden death in every
age, no less naturally procured him that of god of archery. Of any
connection between Apollo and the Sun, whatever may have existed in
the more esoteric doctrine of the Greek sanctuaries, there is no trace
in either Iliad or Odyssey.”—Mure, “History of Greek Literature,” vol.
[51] It has frequently been observed, that most pestilences begin with
animals, and that Homer had this fact in mind.
[52] _Convened to council_. The public assembly in the heroic times is
well characterized by Grote, vol. ii. p 92. “It is an assembly for
talk. Communication and discussion to a certain extent by the chiefs
in person, of the people as listeners and sympathizers—often for
eloquence, and sometimes for quarrel—but here its ostensible purposes
end.”
[53] Old Jacob Duport, whose “Gnomologia Homerica” is full of curious
and useful things, quotes several passages of the ancients, in which
reference is made to these words of Homer, in maintenance of the
belief that dreams had a divine origin and an import in which men were
interested.
[54] Rather, “bright-eyed.” See the German critics quoted by Arnold.
[55] The prize given to Ajax was Tecmessa, while Ulysses received
Laodice, the daughter of Cycnus.
[56] The Myrmidons dwelt on the southern borders of Thessaly, and took
their origin from Myrmido, son of Jupiter and Eurymedusa. It is
fancifully supposed that the name was derived from myrmaex, an _ant_,
“because they imitated the diligence of the ants, and like them were
indefatigable, continually employed in cultivating the earth; the
change from ants to men is founded merely on the equivocation of their
name, which resembles that of the ant: they bore a further resemblance
to these little animals, in that instead of inhabiting towns or
villages, at first they commonly resided in the open fields, having no
other retreats but dens and the cavities of trees, until Ithacus
brought them together, and settled them in more secure and comfortable
habitations.”—Anthon’s “Lempriere.”
[57] Eustathius, after Heraclides Ponticus and others, allegorizes
this apparition, as if the appearance of Minerva to Achilles, unseen
by the rest, was intended to point out the sudden recollection that he
would gain nothing by intemperate wrath, and that it were best to
restrain his anger, and only gratify it by withdrawing his services.
The same idea is rather cleverly worked out by Apuleius, “De Deo
Socratis.”
[58] Compare Milton, “Paradise Lost,” bk. ii:
“Though his tongue
Dropp’d manna.”
So Proverbs v. 3, “For the lips of a strange woman drop as an
honey-comb.”
[59] Salt water was chiefly used in lustrations, from its being
supposed to possess certain fiery particles. Hence, if sea-water could
not be obtained, salt was thrown into the fresh water to be used for
the lustration. Menander, in Clem. Alex. vii. p.713, hydati
perriranai, embalon alas, phakois.
[60] The persons of heralds were held inviolable, and they were at
liberty to travel whither they would without fear of molestation.
Pollux, Onom. viii. p. 159. The office was generally given to old men,
and they were believed to be under the especial protection of Jove and
Mercury.
[61] His mother, Thetis, the daughter of Nereus and Doris, who was
courted by Neptune and Jupiter. When, however, it was known that the
son to whom she would give birth must prove greater than his father,
it was determined to wed her to a mortal, and Peleus, with great
difficulty, succeeded in obtaining her hand, as she eluded him by
assuming various forms. Her children were all destroyed by fire
through her attempts to see whether they were immortal, and Achilles
would have shared the same fate had not his father rescued him. She
afterwards rendered him invulnerable by plunging him into the waters
of the Styx, with the exception of that part of the heel by which she
held him. Hygin. Fab. 54
[62] Thebé was a city of Mysia, north of Adramyttium.
[63] That is, defrauds me of the prize allotted me by their votes.
[64] Quintus Calaber goes still further in his account of the service
rendered to Jove by Thetis:
“Nay more, the fetters of Almighty Jove
She loosed”—Dyce’s “Calaber,” s. 58.
[65] _To Fates averse_. Of the gloomy destiny reigning throughout the
Homeric poems, and from which even the gods are not exempt, Schlegel
well observes, “This power extends also to the world of gods— for the
Grecian gods are mere powers of nature—and although immeasurably
higher than mortal man, yet, compared with infinitude, they are on an
equal footing with himself.”—‘Lectures on the Drama’ v. p. 67.
[66] It has been observed that the annual procession of the sacred
ship so often represented on Egyptian monuments, and the return of the
deity from Ethiopia after some days’ absence, serves to show the
Ethiopian origin of Thebes, and of the worship of Jupiter Ammon. “I
think,” says Heeren, after quoting a passage from Diodorus about the
holy ship, “that this procession is represented in one of the great
sculptured reliefs on the temple of Karnak. The sacred ship of Ammon
is on the shore with its whole equipment, and is towed along by
another boat. It is therefore on its voyage. This must have been one
of the most celebrated festivals, since, even according to the
interpretation of antiquity, Homer alludes to it when he speaks of
Jupiter’s visit to the Ethiopians, and his twelve days’
absence.”—Long, “Egyptian Antiquities” vol. 1 p. 96. Eustathius, vol.
1 p. 98, sq. (ed. Basil) gives this interpretation, and likewise an
allegorical one, which we will spare the reader.
[67] _Atoned_, i.e. reconciled. This is the proper and most natural
meaning of the word, as may be seen from Taylor’s remarks in Calmet’s
Dictionary, p.110, of my edition.
[68] That is, drawing back their necks while they cut their throats.
“If the sacrifice was in honour of the celestial gods, the throat was
bent upwards towards heaven; but if made to the heroes, or infernal
deities, it was killed with its throat toward the ground.”— “Elgin
Marbles,” vol i. p.81.
“The jolly crew, unmindful of the past,
The quarry share, their plenteous dinner haste,
Some strip the skin; some portion out the spoil;
The limbs yet trembling, in the caldrons boil;
Some on the fire the reeking entrails broil.
Stretch’d on the grassy turf, at ease they dine,
Restore their strength with meat, and cheer their souls with wine.”
Dryden’s “Virgil,” i. 293.
[69] _Crown’d, i.e._ filled to the brim. The custom of adorning
goblets with flowers was of later date.
[70] _He spoke_, &c. “When a friend inquired of Phidias what pattern
he had formed his Olympian Jupiter, he is said to have answered by
repeating the lines of the first Iliad in which the poet represents
the majesty of the god in the most sublime terms; thereby signifying
that the genius of Homer had inspired him with it. Those who beheld
this statue are said to have been so struck with it as to have asked
whether Jupiter had descended from heaven to show himself to Phidias,
or whether Phidias had been carried thither to contemplate the god.”—
“Elgin Marbles,” vol. xii p.124.
[71] “So was his will
Pronounced among the gods, and by an oath,
That shook heav’n’s whole circumference, confirm’d.”
“Paradise Lost” ii. 351.
[72] _A double bowl, i.e._ a vessel with a cup at both ends, something
like the measures by which a halfpenny or pennyworth of nuts is sold.
See Buttmann, Lexic. p. 93 sq.
[73] “Paradise Lost,” i. 44.
“Him th’ Almighty power
Hurl’d headlong flaming from th ethereal sky,
With hideous ruin and combustion”
[74] The occasion on which Vulcan incurred Jove’s displeasure was
this—After Hercules, had taken and pillaged Troy, Juno raised a storm,
which drove him to the island of Cos, having previously cast Jove into
a sleep, to prevent him aiding his son. Jove, in revenge, fastened
iron anvils to her feet, and hung her from the sky, and Vulcan,
attempting to relieve her, was kicked down from Olympus in the manner
described. The allegorists have gone mad in finding deep explanations
for this amusing fiction. See Heraclides, “Ponticus,” p. 463 sq., ed
Gale. The story is told by Homer himself in Book xv. The Sinthians
were a race of robbers, the ancient inhabitants of Lemnos which island
was ever after sacred to Vulcan.
“Nor was his name unheard or unadored
In ancient Greece, and in Ausonian land
Men call’d him Mulciber, and how he fell
From heaven, they fabled, thrown by angry Jove
Sheer o’er the crystal battlements from morn
To noon he fell, from noon to dewy eve,
A summer’s day and with the setting sun
Dropp’d from the zenith like a falling star
On Lemnos, th’ Aegean isle thus they relate.”
“Paradise Lost,” i. 738
[75] It is ingeniously observed by Grote, vol i p. 463, that “The gods
formed a sort of political community of their own which had its
hierarchy, its distribution of ranks and duties, its contentions for
power and occasional revolutions, its public meetings in the agora of
Olympus, and its multitudinous banquets or festivals.”
[76] Plato, Rep. iii. p. 437, was so scandalized at this deception of
Jupiter’s, and at his other attacks on the character of the gods, that
he would fain sentence him to an honourable banishment. (See Minucius
Felix, Section 22.) Coleridge, Introd. p. 154, well observes, that the
supreme father of gods and men had a full right to employ a lying
spirit to work out his ultimate will. Compare “Paradise Lost,” v. 646:
“And roseate dews disposed
All but the unsleeping eyes of God to rest.”
[77] —_Dream_ ought to be spelt with a capital letter, being, I think,
evidently personified as the god of dreams. See Anthon and others.
“When, by Minerva sent, a _fraudful_ Dream
Rush’d from the skies, the bane of her and Troy.”
Dyce’s “Select Translations from Quintus Calaber,” p.10.
[78] “Sleep’st thou, companion dear, what sleep can close
Thy eye-lids?”—“Paradise Lost,” v. 673.
[79] This truly military sentiment has been echoed by the approving
voice of many a general and statesman of antiquity. See Pliny’s
Panegyric on Trajan. Silius neatly translates it,
“Turpe duci totam somno consumere noctem.”
